instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What is the methodology for measuring labor income share series at the industry level, and why is the distribution of income between capital, labor, and intermediate inputs important in growth accounting?
output:
The distribution of income between capital, labor, and intermediate inputs is an important element in growth accounting because income shares, under conditions of competitive markets, can be used to measure the contributions each factor makes towards output growth. Under the assumption of constant returns to scale with two factors of production i.e., labor and capital, the sum of the labor income share and capital income share is 1. The labor income share is defined as the ratio of labor income to GVA. Capital income share is accordingly obtained as one minus labor income share.

There are no published data on factor income shares in the Indian economy at a detailed disaggregate level. National Accounts Statistics (NAS) of the CSO publishes the NDP series comprising compensation of employees (CE), operating surplus (OS), and mixed income (MI) for the NAS industries. The income of self-employed persons, i.e., mixed income (MI), is not separated into the labor component and capital component of the income. Therefore, to compute the labor income share out of value added, one has to take the sum of the compensation of employees and that part of the mixed income which are wages for labor.

The computation of labor income share for the 27 study industries involves two steps. First, estimates of CE and MI have to be obtained for each of the 27 study industries from the NAS data, which are available only for the NAS sectors (see Table 7.1). Second, the estimate of mixed income has to be split into labor income and capital income for each industry for each year (except for those industries for which the reported mixed income is zero, for instance, public administration).

input: Question: What data sources and steps are involved in computing the labor income share for 27 study industries?
output: The computation of labor income share for the 27 study industries involves using NAS, ASI, and unit level data of survey of unorganized manufacturing enterprises to obtain estimates of CE, OS, and MI for each of the 27 study industries. To split the labor and non-labor components out of the mixed income of self -employed, the unit level data of NSS employment-unemployment survey are used along with the estimates of CE, OS and MI basically obtained from the NAS. The estimation of labor income share for the 27 study industries is done in two steps: First, estimates of CE, OS and MI are obtained for the 27 study Industries. NAS provides estimates of compensation of employees (CE), operating surplus (OS) and mixed income (MI) for the 9 NAS industries. For some industries under study, for instance (i) Agriculture, forestry & logging and fishing, (ii) Mining & Quarrying, (iii) Electricity, gas and water supply and (iv) Construction, the required data are readily available from NAS. For others, the estimates available in NAS have to be distributed across the study industries using ASI data. The NAS estimates of factor incomes (CE) for registered manufacturing is split into KLMES 13 industries (3-15) in proportion to the reported ASI data on emoluments for various industries. Estimate of factor incomes for ‘other services’ in NAS has been split into estimates for (i) Education, (ii) Health and Social Work, and (iii) Other Community, Social and Personal Services including Renting of Machinery and Business Services, and Private Household with Employed Persons. Before 2011 -12, NAS provides estimates of factor incomes for registered manufacturing and unregistered manufacturing, but not for individual manufacturing industries. However, 2011 -12 onwards NAS disaggregated the manufacturing sector in corporate sector and household sector.  The NAS estimates of factor incomes for registered manufacturing and corporate sector have to be split into various manufacturing industries considered in the study (13 in number) using ASI data. The reported CE in NAS for registered manufacturing and corporate sector has been distributed into those 13 industries in proportion to the reported ASI data on emoluments for various industries. input: Question: How are Compensation of Employees (CE), Operating Surplus (OS), and Mixed Income (MI) estimated for the 27 study industries, particularly regarding the distribution of OS for registered manufacturing and corporate sectors, and how is the data handled for unorganized manufacturing?
output: For estimating Compensation of Employees (CE), Operating Surplus (OS) and Mixed Income (MI) for the 27 study industries, the following procedure is used: Using ASI data, the estimate of OS for registered manufacturing and corporate sector has been distributed. Emoluments are subtracted from gross value added for various industries yielding capital income. The share of different industries in aggregate capital income of organized manufacturing indicated by the ASI data is used to split the estimate of OS for registered manufacturing and corporate sector reported in the NAS. The methodology applied for unregistered manufacturing and household sector is similar, utilizing published results and unit level data of survey of unorganized manufacturing industries to split (proportionately) the estimate of CE in the NAS for aggregate unregistered manufacturing. The estimated wage payment is subtracted from the estimated value added to obtain an estimate of capital income and mixed income of the self -employed in various unorganized manufacturing industries. The estimate of MI provided in NAS for unregistered manufacturing and household sector has then been proportionately distributed across industries using the estimate of capital income and mixed income of the self-employed in various industries that could be formed on the basis of published results and unit level data of survey of unorganized manufacturing industries. Unlike the ASI data for organized manufacturing, the data for unorganized manufacturing enterprises are available for only select years and interpolation/extrapolation is used to obtain the relevant proportions for other years.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How is the estimation method of \u03b7 (the labour income proportion in income) described and implemented?
output:
The estimation of \u03b7 has been done with the help of NSS survey-based estimates of employment of different categories of workers (number of persons and days of work) and wage rates (which has been described briefly in chapter 4) coupled with estimates of MI, basically obtained from the NAS. Two approaches have been taken to get an estimate of \u03b7, and the labour income share series for different industries finally adopted in the study makes use of an average of the estimates of \u03b7 obtained by the two approaches.

In the first approach, an estimate of labour income of self-employed workers has been made for each study industry for eight years, 1983-84, 1987-88, 1993-94, 1999-00, 2004-05, 2009-10, 2011-12 and 2015-16 on the basis of the estimated number of self-employed, wage rate of self-employed and the number of days of work per week. The industry-wise estimates of number of self-employed, wage rate of self-employed and the number of days of work per week have been made from unit records of NSS employment -unemployment survey (major rounds) of 1983, 1993 -94, 1999-00, 2004-05, 2011-12, and PLFS of 2018-19, 2019-20 and 2020-21.

The estimates of the number of self-employed, wage rate of self-employed and the number of days of work per week provide an estimate of the annul labour income of self-employed workers which is divided by the mixed income of self-employed (derived from NAS) to get an estimate of \u03b7. For five industries, the ratio in question has been computed and applied. For the other 22 industries, the ratio in question has been computed after clubbing the industries into 11 industry groups. In the latter case, a common ratio computed for group of industries has then been applied to constituent industries. The list of industries or industry groups for which \u03b7 has been estimated is given in table 7.2.

In the second approach, the NSS data are used to compute the following ratio: the ratio of labour income of self-employed workers to the labour income of regular and casual workers. Let this be denoted by \u03b8. Then, the estimate of CE provided in the NAS is multiplied by \u03b8 to obtain an estimate of the labour income component out of the MI reported in the NAS. The labour component of MI divided by total MI gives an estimate of \u03b7. In case the estimated labour component of MI exceeds the estimate of MI, the estimate of \u03b7 has been taken as unity.

Examining the estimates obtained by the first approach, it was found that the estimated labour income share out of mixed income varied significantly among the estimates for the seven years for which the ratio in question has been estimated.

input: Question: How is the labour income share computed, and what steps are taken to address potential issues in its estimation?
output: The estimates of 𝜂 obtained by the second approach has the problem that in a number of cases, the estimated labor component of MI exceeds the estimate of MI given in the NAS, and therefore 𝜂 is taken as one. The method finally adopted is as follows: (a) The average value of 𝜂 has been computed for each industry or industry group by taking the estimates for the years 1983-84, 1987-88, 1993-94, 1999-00, 2004-05, 2009-10, 2011-12 and 2015-16. This has been done separately for the estimates based on approach-1 and those based on approach-2. (b) The estimates of 𝜂 obtained for each industry or industry group by the two approaches have then been averaged. (c) Having obtained an estimate of 𝜂, equation 7.1 has been applied to compute the labour income share. Equation 7.1 is defined as SL it = (CE it +MIit) /GVAit, where SL it is the labour income share in industry i in year t, CE it is compensation of employees in industry i in year t, MIit is mixed income of the self-employed persons in industry i in year t, and GVAit is gross value added in industry i in year t.

input: Question: How are the income shares of labor, capital, and intermediate inputs in Gross Output computed?
output:
The income shares of labor, capital, and intermediate inputs in Gross output are computed using the following steps:

First, the individual shares of intermediate inputs (energy, material, and services) in Gross output are calculated.
Then, the labor income and capital income out of Gross Value Added are further distributed into the income share of labor in gross output and the income share of capital in gross output.
This provides the share of labor, capital, material, energy, and services in output.
For the Agriculture Sector, land is taken as an input. First, the income share of intermediate inputs in gross output is calculated. Then, the non-labor income (out of value added) in Agriculture is distributed equally between land and capital inputs to derive weights.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What is the methodology for measuring total factor productivity (TFP) growth for individual industries in the KLEMS framework, and how does it aggregate from industry-level productivity measures to measures for broad sectors and the economy as a whole?
output: This chapter deals with the methodology of measurement of total factor productivity (TFP) growth for individual industries in the KLEMS framework and the aggregation from industry level productivity measures to measures for broad sectors and the economy as a whole. The methodology of analysis of sources of gross output growth at the individual industry level and sources of GVA (Gross Value Added) or GDP growth at the broad sector level and economy level will also be presented in this chapter. The measurement of TFP growth for different industries of the Indian economy is based on a gross output production function for each industry j: Y = f(L(L1,…Ln), K(K1…Km), E(E1….Es), M(M1 …Mu), S(S1 … Sv ), T) where Y is industry gross output, L is labor input, K is capital input and E, M and S are intermediate inputs-namely energy, material and services and T is an indicator of technology for industry j. All variables are indexed by time (t subscript is suppressed). An important feature of the gross output approach is the explicit role of intermediate inputs, considering energy, material and services. Failure to quantify intermediate inputs leads to missing the role of key industries that produce intermediate inputs and the importance of intermediate inputs for the industries that use them.

input: Question: How is Total Factor Productivity (TFP) growth estimated, and what is the growth accounting decomposition of output growth?
output:
Total Factor Productivity:

To estimate TFP growth, we begin with the fundamental accounting identity for each industry where the value of output equals the value of inputs:

𝑷𝒀,𝒋𝒀𝒋 = 𝑷𝑲,𝒋𝑲𝒋 + 𝑷𝑳,𝒋𝑳𝒋 + 𝑷𝑬,𝒋𝑬𝒋 + 𝑷𝑴,𝒋𝑴𝒋 + 𝑷𝑺,𝒋𝑺𝒋 (8.2)

Under specific assumptions of constant returns to scale and competitive markets, we can define TFP growth as:

𝝊𝑻,𝒋 ≡ ∆𝒍𝒏𝒀𝒋 − 𝝊̅𝑲,𝒋∆𝒍𝒏𝑲𝒋 − 𝝊̅𝑳,𝒋𝚫𝒍𝒏𝑳𝒋 − 𝝊̅𝑬,𝒋𝚫𝒍𝒏𝑬𝒋 − 𝝊̅𝑴,𝒋𝚫𝒍𝒏𝑴𝒋 − 𝝊̅𝑺,𝒋𝚫𝒍𝒏𝑺𝒋 (8.3)

Where 𝒗̅ is the two-period average share of the input in the nominal value of output.

We define the value share of each input as:

𝒗𝒊,𝒋 =

and 𝑋𝐾,𝑗 = 𝐾𝑗, 𝑋𝐿,𝑗 =𝐿𝑗, 𝑋𝐸,𝑗 = 𝐸𝑗 , 𝑋𝑀,𝑗 =𝑀𝑗𝑋𝑆,𝑗 = 𝑆𝑗 ;

and 𝒗̅𝒊,𝒋 = 0.5 (𝒗𝒊,𝒋,𝑡 + 𝒗𝒊,𝒋,𝒕−𝟏 ) (8.5)

The assumption of constant returns to scale implies ∑ 𝒗𝒊,𝒋𝒊 = 1 and allows the use of observed value shares for the calculation of TFP growth in equation (8.3).

Rearranging equation (8.3), yields the standard growth accounting decomposition of output growth into the contribution of each input and the TFP residual:

∆𝒍𝒏𝒀𝒋 = 𝝊̅𝑲,𝒋∆𝒍𝒏𝑲𝒋 + 𝝊̅𝑳,𝒋𝚫𝒍𝒏𝑳𝒋 + 𝝊̅𝑬,𝒋𝚫𝒍𝒏𝑬𝒋 + 𝝊̅𝑴,𝒋𝚫𝒍𝒏𝑴𝒋 + 𝝊̅𝑺,𝒋𝚫𝒍𝒏𝑺𝒋 + 𝝊𝑻,𝒋 (8.6)

where the contribution of an input is defined as the product of the input’s growth rate and its two period average value share. Input and output are constructed using industry level price data for capital, labor and intermediate inputs. For example, PYj; PLj, PKj; PEj. PMj, PSj. The industry price of an input varies across industries due to compositional effects as industries expend different shares of their investment on each type of asset; the same is true for all inputs.

input: Question: How can the contribution of each input be further decomposed, and what does the extended decomposition of the sources of output growth look like?
output:
The contribution of each input can be further decomposed into a quantity and quality component. The quality component represents substitution between components, while the quantity component represents the increases in each detailed input. The extended decomposition of the sources of output growth is given as follows:
∆𝒍𝒏𝒀𝒋 = 𝝊̅𝑲,𝒋 (∆𝒍𝒏𝒁𝒋 + 𝚫𝒍𝒏𝑸𝑲,𝒋) + 𝝊̅𝑳,𝒋(𝚫𝒍𝒏𝑯𝒋 +  𝚫𝒍𝒏𝑸𝑳,𝒋) + 𝝊̅𝑬,𝒋𝚫𝒍𝒏𝑬𝒋 + 𝝊̅𝑴,𝒋𝚫𝒍𝒏𝑴𝒋 +
𝝊̅𝑺,𝒋𝚫𝒍𝒏𝑺𝒋 + 𝝊𝑻,𝒋 (8.7) 
Where Z is the stock of industry capital, Qk is the capital quality, H is number of persons employed and Ql is the quality of labour. The data series at individual industry level constructed for gross value added and gross output, labour input, capital input, intermediate inputs and factor income shares (described in Chapters 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 respectively) are used to estimate TFPG during the period 1980 to 2019. Labour input is measured by using total person worked along with the labour quality index (see Chapter 4 for a detailed discussion). The series on growth rate in capital services forms the measure of growth in capital input (discussed in Chapter 5). TFPG estimation is done by using the gross output function framework (i.e. equation 8.7).

input: Question: How are aggregates for the economy obtained using the Törnqvist index, and what formulas are used to calculate output and input aggregates for sector J?
output:
Aggregates for the economy are obtained using the Törnqvist aggregate of growth rates of real value added, capital input, and labor input. Suppose the aggregate sector J consists of n KLEMS industries (j=1:n). The output (value added) and input aggregates for sector J are calculated as follows:

∆𝑙𝑛𝑉𝐽 = ∑ 𝑣̅𝑗𝑗 ∆𝑙𝑛𝑉𝑗 (8.8)
∆𝑙𝑛𝐾𝐽 = ∑ 𝑤̅𝑗𝐾𝑗 ∆𝑙𝑛𝐾𝑗 (8.9)
∆𝑙𝑛𝐿𝐽 = ∑ 𝑤̅𝑗𝐿𝑗 ∆𝑙𝑛𝐿𝑗 (8.10)

where 𝑣̅𝑗 is nominal value added share, 𝑤̅𝑗𝐾 is the cost share of capital (i.e., the share of rental cost), and 𝑤̅𝑗𝐿 is the labor compensation share – all shares are calculated for KLEMS industry j, in the aggregate sector J, i.e.,

𝑣𝑗 = 𝑃𝑉,𝑗𝑉𝑗 / ∑ 𝑃𝑉,𝑗𝑉𝑗𝑗
𝑤𝑗𝐾 = 𝑃𝐾,𝑗𝑆𝑗 / ∑ 𝑃𝐾,𝑗𝑆𝑗𝑗
𝑤𝑗𝐿 = 𝑃𝐿,𝑗𝐻𝑗 / ∑ 𝑃𝐿,𝑗𝐻𝑗𝑗 (8.11)

where PV,j is the price of value added in industry j, V j is the real value added in industry j, P K,j is the rental price of capital in industry j, S j is the capital stock in industry j, P L,j is the wage rate (price of labor) in industry j, and H j is the employment in industry j. The aggregate output (real value added) and input growth rates obtained above are then used with the growth accounting equation to obtain the sectoral TFP growth rates.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What does the India KLEMS database version 2024 include, what industries does it cover, and what period does it span?
output:
This document describes the procedures, methodologies and approaches used in the construction of India KLEMS database version 2024. The dataset includes measures of Gross Value Added (GVA), Gross Value of Output (GVO), Labour Employment (L), Labour Quality (LQ), Capital Stock (K), Capital Composition (KQ), the consumptions of Energy (E), Material (M) and Services (S) inputs, Labour Productivity (LP) and Total Factor Productivity (TFP). The database covers 27 industries comprising of the entire Indian economy. The database also provides these estimates at the broad sectoral levels (agriculture, manufacturing and services) and at the all-India levels. The current version of the database covers the period from 1980-81 to 2022-23. The series have been constructed on the basis of data compiled from NSO, NSSO, ASI, Input -Output tables (I- O tables) and processed according to appropriate procedures. These procedures were developed to ensure harmonization of the basic data, and to generate growth accounts in a consistent and uniform way. Harmonization of the basic data has focused on several areas such as industrial classification, and aggregation levels.
The production and publication of India KLEMS data base are meant to support empirical research in the area of economic growth and its sources. Most importantly, the database is meant to support the conduct of policies aimed at supporting the acceleration of productivity growth in the Indian economy. The India KLEMS database, in this regard, provides a comprehensive measurement tool to monitor and evaluate productivity growth in the Indian economy. Finally, the construction of the database would also support the systematic production of reliable statistics on growth and productivity using internationally comparable methodologies based on India’s national accounts, input-output tables and labour market surveys.
The work relating to compilation of India KLEMS data was being done by the India KLEMS team housed at the Centre for Development Economics, Delhi School of Economics until the end of 2020. The work has been shifted to the KLEMS Division of the Department of Economics and Policy Research of RBI since February 2021The current version of the India KLEMS Database, released hereby, is the third independent compilation of this data by the KLEMS Division in RBI, after the previous release of the data in January 2024.

input: Question: What industries are covered in the India KLEMS database, and what data sources are used to construct the series?
output: The India KLEMS database covers 27 industries, aggregated into six broad sectors: Agriculture, Hunting, Forestry and Fishing; Mining and Quarrying; Manufacturing; Electricity, Gas and Water supply; Construction; and Services. Measures of Capital (K), Labour (L), Energy (E), Material (M) and Service (S) inputs as well as Gross Output (GO), have been constructed using National Accounts Statistics (NAS), Annual Survey of Industries (ASI), NSSO rounds and Input -Output (IO) Tables. In building annual time series on gross output, five inputs and factor income shares, various assumptions are made to fill up gaps in industry details and link series over time. NSSO rounds of unregistered manufacturing, Input Output Transaction Tables, and Employment and Unemployment Surveys by NSSO are available only for certain benchmark years, necessitating interpolation and assumption of constant shares for building series of output and inputs. However, as the successor of NSSO's Employment Unemployment Survey, the Periodic Labour Force Survey (PLFS) data has become available annually since 2017-18, the labour input series no longer requires any extrapolation. The labour input series is being updated under each round of India KLEMS using available survey data from PLFS only. The industrial classification is constructed by building concordance between NIC 2008, NIC 2004, NIC 1998, NIC 1987 and NIC 1970 to generate a uniform definition of ‘industries’ since 1980-81 and is close to the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC) revision 3.

input: Question: What data sources and methodologies are used to construct the Gross Value Added (GVA) series at current and constant prices for the 27 study industries, and what are the key steps involved in the construction process?
output:
This chapter describes the data sources and methodology used to construct the Gross Value Added (GVA) series at current and constant prices for 27 study industries for the period of 1980-81 (1980) to 2022-23(2023). The construction of Gross valued added series involves three steps.

Step 1: A concordance table between the classification used in the National Accounts Statistics (NAS) and the 27 study industry classification used for this project has been prepared. Further, concordance between all the 27 sectors has been constructed with NIC - 1970, 1987, 1998, 2004 and 2008. Out of the 27 study industries, for 20 industries, GVA series both in current and constant prices is directly taken from NAS. The sectors for which data are provided in NAS are Agriculture, Forest ry & logging, Fishing, Mining and Quarrying, Manufacturing, Electricity, gas and water supply, Construction, Trade, Hotels & Restaurants, Railways, Transport by other means, Storage, Communication, Banking & insurance, Real estate, Ownership of Dwelling & Business Services, Public Administration & Defense and Other Services.

Step 2: For manufacturing industries where direct estimates of GVA were not available from NAS, estimates have been made using additional information from ASI and NSSO unorganised manufacturing data. In these cases, GVA data is constructed by splitting the NAS data using ASI or NSSO distributions. ASI data (annual) has been used for registered and corporate manufacturing, whereas interpolated ratios from NSSO 40th (1984-85), 45th (1989-90), 51st (1994-95), 56th (2000-01), 62nd (2005-06), 67th round (2010-11) and 73rd round (2015-16) rounds have been used.

input: Question: What procedures and methodologies are employed to construct the database for gross output series at the industry level from 1980 to 2023, and what data sources are utilized?
output: This chapter describes the procedures and methodologies used in constructing the database for gross output series at the industry level over the period 1980-81(1980) to 2022-2023(2023). To construct the gross output series at industry level, multiple data sources are used, namely National Accounts Statistics, Annual Survey of Industries, NSSO rounds for unorganized manufacturing and Input Output Transaction tables. The NAS is the basic source of data for the construction of time series on the gross output. For years since 2011, the estimates of GVO both at current and constant prices for all industries are taken directly from NAS 2024. For a few industry groups at a more aggregate level, requiring splitting of the aggregates, NAS estimates of output have been split using additional information from the Annual Survey of Industries and NSSO rounds of Unregistered Manufacturing to obtain estimates at a higher level of disaggregation. For Unregistered manufacturing, gross output data is available in NAS from 2004- 05 onwards, and information from NSSO survey rounds has been used for missing years to derive output estimates of unregistered manufacturing industries at current and constant prices. For the gross value-added series of service sectors, estimates are obtained from NAS. However, prior to 2011- 12, National Accounts did not provide any estimates of the gross output of service sectors and hence Input output transaction tables are relied on (from which the ratio of gross to value added is computed which is then applied to GVA reported in NAS) which are available at an interval of 5 years or so. This necessitates interpolation and assumption of constant shares for measuring output of services sectors. The Input Output Transaction Tables for Benchmark years of 1978-79, 1983-84, 1989-90, 1993-94, 1998-99, 2003-04 and 2007-08 are used to derive gross output series for service sectors.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How is labor input constructed for 27 industries from 1980-81 to 2022-23, and what data sources are used in the estimation?
output: This chapter discusses the construction of labour input for 27 industries from 1980-81 to 2022-23. Labour input captures both the quantity of labour ( i.e. number of persons) and quality of labour over time. Labour quality is measured based on educational qualification and wage rates of the workers within each of the 27 industries . Given the limitations of India’s employment statistics (Sivasubramonian; 2004, & Himanshu; 2011, Ghose; 2016), especially the availability of information on wages/ earnings of different category of workers across industries, the database provides only the labour quality index based on five different education categories. Labour input is measured by multiplying the number of persons employed by the index of labour quality which captures the human capital embodied in the labour, constructed separately for each industry. The 38th to 68th rounds of the Employment and Unemployment Survey (EUS) by India’s National Sample Survey Office (NSSO) conducted between 1983 and 2011- 12, respectively, and all the annual Periodic Labour Force Survey (PLFS) rounds from 2017-18 to 2022- 23 by National Statistical Organization (NSO) are the main sou rces data for estimating labour input. We use India’s decadal census and population projections based on Government of India’s various reports for estimating India’s population.  The total employment, measured by the number of persons engaged in each of the 27 industries in India is computed as follows: 1. First, the concordance between 27 KLEMS industries was built with each of NIC-1970, 1987, 1998 and 2008, separately. 2. Based on each round of EUS and PLFS, the distributions of workers by UPSS across the four groups - Rural Male, Rural Female, Urban Male and Urban Fem ale were obtained. These distributions of workers were then multiplied with the all-India figures for the number of workers for each of the years of EUS and PLFS rounds. 3. The all -India figures for the number of workers are generally not directly available from any official sources. We obtain the official estimates of worker-population ratios (WPR) from each of the EUS.

input: Question: How is the total employment computed for each of the 27 industries in India?
output:
The total employment, measured by the number of persons engaged in each of the 27 industries in India is computed as follows:
1. First, the concordance between 27 KLEMS industries was built with each of NIC-1970, 1987, 1998 and 2008, separately.
2. Based on each round of EUS and PLFS, the distributions of workers by UPSS across the four groups - Rural Male, Rural Female, Urban Male and Urban Female were obtained. These distributions of workers were then multiplied with the all-India figures for the number of workers for each of the years of EUS and PLFS rounds.
3. The all -India figures for the number of workers are generally not directly available from any official sources. The official estimates of worker-population ratios (WPR) are obtained from each of the survey rounds and multiply them with India’s total population for the survey year. India’s population for the survey years is obtained by interpolating India’s decadal census populations.
4. For 2017-18, 2018-19 and 2019-20, the all-India figures for number of employed persons were available from the Government of India (See Table 7 on pg. no 371 of Economic Survey 2021-22, Government of India (https://www.indiabudget.gov.in/budget2022-23/economicsurvey/doc/echapter.pdf).)
5. For 2020-21 onwards, India’s population growth projections by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare 2020 (See Table 8on pg. 44 on https://main.mohfw.gov.in/sites/default/files/Population%20Projection%20Report%202011-2036%20-%20upload_compressed_0.pdf ) are used. These projections are available for male and female separately, at the all-India level. The growth projection for all-India male (female) population for both urban male (female) and rural male (female) is used.
6. Finally, L ij is obtained for each industry where i=1 for rural and 2 for urban sectors, and j=1 for male and 2 for female for each round.
7. Total persons employed in a year were then obtained for each industry as the sum of the Lij over gender and sectors, i.e., ΣiΣjLij.
8. The estimates of employment for the intervening years between each of the EUS and PLFS rounds are obtained by simple interpolation across the four segments- rural male, rural females, urban male and the urban females for all of the 27 industries separately.
9. The mid-points of the surveys are around the mid-year of the survey rounds, i.e. July for 38th round and 1st Jan for the other rounds; whereas the interpolation has been centered around 1st October which is the mid-year of the national income estimates (This is also the mid-point of financial year.). Hence, the base is shifted to October of each year while interpolating the values (For more detailed discussion on extrapolation and interpolation of the series, readers may refer to KLMES data manual version 2022 released by RBI on its website.). This is done to coincide the survey year mid-point to the mid-point of financial year.
For extrapolation backward to 1980- 81 to 1982- 83, the interpolation of the broad industrial classifications of 32nd round (1977-78) and 38thround (1983-84) are used. Thus, the estimates from 32nd round are mainly used as control numbers. Between 2005 and 2011, there was a very high growth rate in number of employed persons series for the industry Electrical and Optical Equipment as compared to other manufacturing industries and the overall growth in employment in this industry during 2005-2011 was found to be higher than that for Construction (which seems somewhat unrealistic). instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How is the Labour Quality Index estimated and used in the India KLEMS database, and what adjustments were made to the employment estimates for specific industries?
output:
To address issues with employment estimates, particularly a high growth rate in the Electrical and Optical Equipment industry between 2005 and 2011 compared to other manufacturing industries and negative growth in Textiles, Textile Products, Leather, and Footwear despite real GVA doubling, adjustments were made. Specifically, the difference between the estimated employment series from EUS rounds and those based on ASI & NSSO rounds for the Electrical and Optical Equipment industry is computed and added to the Textiles, Textile Products, Leather, and Footwear industry. This ensures that, for manufacturing as a whole, the estimates remain the same as obtained from EUS rounds.

The quality of the labor force is measured using the Jorgenson, Gollop, and Fraumeni (JGF) (1987) methodology.  This involves accounting for changes in labor quality in terms of labor characteristics such as educational attainment, age (experience), gender, and employment status to reflect the heterogeneity of the labor force.  In the India KLEMS study, the index of aggregate labor quality measures changes in the composition of labor in the economy. The present study computes the labor quality index using only education as a characteristic in the JGF methodology. The data required is employment and earnings by education and by industry. The labor quality index is computed using five education categories: up to primary, primary, middle, secondary & higher secondary, and above higher secondary. The quality growth rates are estimated for total persons employed in 27 study industries in India, based on various rounds of the EUS by NSSO and PLFS since 2017-18, and indexed to 1983-84 as the base to assess temporal changes in labor’s skill. Interpolation is done between major rounds for intermediate years, and the series is extrapolated backwards from 1983-84 to 1980-81, with the index recomputed to set 1980-81 equal to 100. The following steps have been performed: 1. Compute the distribution of persons employed by the five educational groups for all the 27 industries for the selected major rounds of EUS and PLFS. 2. Apply these proportions to the number of employed persons in different industries in the major rounds and PLFS to obtain the distribution of persons by education groups. 3. Estimate the earnings data from NSO which relates mainly to the regular and casual persons employed. For employed persons whose wage information is missing, a Mincer equation is used.

To estimate the earnings for self-employed persons, a Mincer wage equation is used, corrected for sample selection bias using Heckman’s two-step procedures. The Mincer function is applied to the earnings of casual and regular employees, where earnings are regressed on dummies of age, gender, education, location (rural or urban), marital status, social exclusion, and industry. The corresponding earnings of the self-employed are obtained as the predicted value with similar traits. The average wages per day are then computed for persons employed of different types of employment, i.e., self-employed, regular, and casual combined together; whose wages are available.
Based on steps 1 to 3, the labor quality index is estimated as equation 4.1:

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What methodology is used to estimate capital services for the 27 industries in the India KLEMS database version 2024, and how is the estimation of capital service growth rate accomplished?
output: This chapter outlines the methodology employed to estimate capital Services for the 27 industries in India KLEMS database version 2024. All the productivity calculations in India KLEMS use capital services as an input to production, which is estimated using the approach developed by Jorgenson and Griliches (1967), and outlined in Jorgenson, Gollop, and Fraumeni (1987). The estimation of capital service growth rate is accomplished by first estimating capi tal stock for different assets, and then aggregating them across assets after correcting for the differences in their marginal productivities. Capital services account for the differences in marginal productivity between different asset types while capital stock measures only the vintages of capital, they do not account for asset heterogeneity. For instance, aggregate capital stock measures would assume that a computer's productivity is the same as that of a car. However, proper measures of capital stock would account for the decline in the efficiency of both computers and cars over their lifetime. Following an overview of the theoretical method to measure capital services (Jorgenson and Griliches,1967; JGF, 1987), the chapter discusses the specific empirical approaches we follow to implement these methods within the constraints of data availability for Indian industries. In India KLEMS, we have reported capital stock, capital services and th e capital “capital composition effect”. Capital stock is reported in constant price volumes, and growth rates, while the latter two are reported in growth rates and indices.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How are capital services measured, and what are the key components and calculations involved?
output: The measurement of capital services involves several components and calculations. First, \(v_{k,t}\) is the share of asset k in total capital compensation, calculated as \(v_{k,t} = \frac{P_{k,t}^K \cdot K_{k,t}}{\sum P_{k,t}^K \cdot K_{k,t}}\, where \(P_{k,t}^K\) is the rental or user cost of capital asset type k in year t, and \(K_{k,t}\) is the capital stock of asset k. This share incorporates the productivity or qualitative differences of various asset types, reflecting that changes in capital composition, such as towards ICT capital, will result in higher capital services.  \nCapital stock in asset k in year t is constructed using the Perpetual Inventory Method (PIM) as: \(S_{k,t} = S_{k,t-1}(1 - \delta_k) + I_{k,t}\), where \(S_{k,t}\) is the capital stock, \(\delta_k\) is the depreciation rate, and \(I_{k,t}\) is the real investment in asset type k in period t.  \nThe capital composition effect (\(\Delta \ln KK_t\))—the effect of changing asset composition—is calculated as \(\Delta \ln KK_t = \Delta \ln K_t - \Delta \ln S_t\), where \(S_t = \sum S_{k,t}^k\). These growth rates are indexed to a base year to obtain a capital composition index \(KK_t\), such that \(KK_t = KK_{t-1} \times e^{(\Delta \ln K_t - \Delta \ln S_t)}\) for t > base year, and \(KK_t = 100\) for t = base year.

input: Question: What data sources and methodologies are used to construct the database on capital services, ensuring consistency and international comparability?
output:
The database on capital services is constructed using multiple sources of information, including the National Accounts Statistics (NAS), the Annual Survey of Industries (ASI), the National Sample Survey Office (NSSO) rounds for unorganized manufacturing, and various Input-Output tables. These sources provide information on broad sectors of the economy and detailed asset-by-industry investment matrices. The final estimates are fully consistent with the aggregate data obtained from the NAS. Additionally, the approach to capital measurement aligns with international practices such as the EU KLEMS, facilitating international comparisons. 

Specifically, NAS provides information on aggregate capital formation by industry of use for nine broad sectors. More detailed data on assets and industries are collected from the CSO (Central Statistical Organization). For sectors where investment matrices are unavailable from CSO, information is gathered from other sources like ASI for organized manufacturing and NSSO surveys for unorganized manufacturing, which is then benchmarked to the aggregate investment series from the National Accounts. The data used in the current version of the India KLEMS is based on the revised NAS with a 2011-2012 base and is available since 2012. For earlier years, the series is extrapolated using growth rates from previous versions of the data. Investment data in education and health sectors are obtained directly from national accounts for the period after 2012, while trends in output distribution are assumed to split total investment into sub-sectors for years before 2012.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the capital asset types in National Accounts Statistics and the corresponding assets in India KLEMS according to Table 5.1?
output: Table 5.1 outlines the capital asset types in National Accounts Statistics (NAS) and their corresponding assets in India KLEMS. For the public sector, NAS asset types include Buildings*, Other construction*, Transport Equipment, Machinery & Equipment, Software (1999-00 onwards), and ICT equipment (2012 onwards). These correspond to Construction, Construction, Transport Equipment, and Machinery & Equipment in India KLEMS, with Software and ICT equipment also included under Machinery & Equipment**. For the private sector, NAS asset types are Residential buildings, Non-residential building, Other construction, Machinery & Equipment (incl. transport equipment), Software (1999-00 onwards) and ICT equipment (2012 onwards). These correspond to Construction, Construction, Construction, and Machinery & Equipment (transport equipment is excluded later*), with Software and ICT equipment also included under Machinery & Equipment** in India KLEMS. Source: CSO, NAS Different Issues. Note: * Buildings and other construction include dwellings, non-residential buildings, roads & bridges, and other construction. ** Software and ICT are included in the machinery and equipment, as we are not distinguishing between ICT and non -ICT assets in this version. *** Transport equipment was not separately available for the private sector, and therefore, it was imputed and subtracted from machinery and equipment (See main text). Also, transport equipment was not separately available for both public and private sectors since 2016, and therefore, we used a fixed proportion of transport equipment to total machinery and equipment from 2016.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How is total investment calculated for each asset category, and what adjustments are made for specific sectors and time periods?
output:
Total investment in each asset category is calculated as the sum of private and public-sector investment in each asset. Investment in transport equipment was not available separately for the private sector industries. Therefore, the NAS total machinery in the private sector was distributed using the industry distribution of machinery and transport equipment. These estimates are then subtracted from each industry’s total machinery & transport equipment data to obtain the transport equipment investment in the private sector industries. Using this approach, investment in transport equipment by industries was generated for the period 1950-2016. The share of transport equipment in the total machinery and equipment was assumed to remain unchanged in subsequent years while estimating nominal investment in transport equipment similarly. The nominal investment was deflated using the GFCF deflator for transport equipment. Since the distinction between registered and unregistered manufacturing is not available in the NAS since 2016, a quick fix was used to split these two by considering the household sector as a proxy for unregistered and the corporate and public sector as a proxy for the registered sector.

Updates for years since 2017-18 are solely based on published aggregate GFCF data from the National Accounts. While extending the past series of detailed asset-wise investments forward for years since 2017-18 using the NAS-published headline series, the published NAS series is considered as the benchmark since 2012. Then the industry distribution of the 2012-2016 detailed series obtained previously from the CSO is applied.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How is gross fixed capital formation by asset type derived from ASI data, and how are inconsistencies addressed?
output:
Gross fixed capital formation by asset type is derived from the yearly detailed volumes of the ASI, beginning 1964-65. For the years 1964-1978, the data is obtained from published detailed volumes. For the period 1983-84 to 2004-05, ASI generated detailed tables from Block C of the ASI schedule, containing data on fixed assets. Data for the missing years are interpolated using changes in investment based on the book value method. Though ASI provides investment in land, for reasons of NAS consistency, it is excluded from the database.

Once investment in each of these assets and industries is generated using ASI data, this industry-asset distribution is applied to the published aggregate NAS GFCF series for the organized manufacturing sector.  From 1960-61 to 1971-72, ASI data is for the census sector, and from 1973-74 onwards, it is for the factory sector. To make these two series comparable, data prior to 1972 is converted to the factory sector using the factory/census ratio in 1973.  This provides investment data for 13 manufacturing sectors, by asset types, consistent with the NAS aggregate for registered manufacturing. This approach was accurate for the period 1950-2016 when the NAS provided aggregate registered manufacturing GFCF data. For the years after 2016, since NAS does not provide registered manufacturing aggregate, registered manufacturing is proxied by the sum of the public sector and corporate sector.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How is the gross investment series created for the 13 sectors of the unorganized manufacturing sector, and what data sources and methods are used for investment prices, initial stock, depreciation rates, and rate of return?
output:
The data required for creating the gross investment series for the 13 sectors of the unorganized manufacturing sector are obtained from various rounds of NSSO surveys on unorganized manufacturing. Six rounds of NSSO surveys are used, covering the period 1989-2016. These are the 45th round (1989-90), 51st round (1994-94), 56th round (2000-01), 62nd round (2005-06), 67th round (2010-11), and 73rd round (2015-16). Unit-level data has been aggregated to 13 industries using the appropriate concordance. NSSO provides net addition to owned assets during the reference year within the block of fixed assets, and this is used as a measure of investment. The investment series arrived at for six rounds were interpolated to obtain the annual time series of unorganized gross fixed capital formation by asset type. As in the case of the registered sector, once the investment by asset types across industries are constructed, the asset-industry distribution is applied to the published NAS aggregate GFCF in unregistered manufacturing to obtain NAS consistent GFCF by asset type and industries.

To compute asset-wise capital stock using PIM (equation 5.3) and rental price (see Box 5.1A in the Appendix), asset-wise investment price deflators are required. Since CSO has provided investment data by industries and assets both in current and constant prices, price deflators with base 2011-2012 could be derived. For years before 2011, prices were spliced using 2004-2005 base investment deflators. These deflators are directly used for all the three asset categories. Since there was no separate asset wise data available for transport equipment in 2017-2018, the investment deflator for transport equipment from 2016-2017 was extrapolated using the trend in the investment price of total machinery & equipment, obtained from NAS.

For the implementation of PIM to estimate asset wise capital stock, an estimate of initial benchmark stock is required. NAS provides estimates of net capital stock since 1950 for all the broad sectors in its Statement 17: Net Fixed Capital Stock by industry of use. The NAS estimate of real net capital stock in 1950 (in 1999-2000 prices) is taken as the benchmark stock for all non-manufacturing sectors, and for manufacturing sectors the same is taken for the year 1964. However, since the NAS estimate is available only for broad sectors and for aggregate capital, the industry-asset distribution of GFCF is used to create net fixed capital stock estimates by asset type for all the 27 sectors. The approach to split asset-wise capital stock is changed in the 2020 version of the India KLEMS database. Instead of using the GFCF distribution, the distribution of net capital stock is used.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How does the India KLEMS database use asset data and depreciation rates to compute capital input, and what source is used for the rate of return?
output: The 2020 version of the India KLEMS database uses detailed asset data obtained from the CSO to determine the distribution of net capital stock by assets. This replaces the GFCF distribution used previously. While the impact of this change on individual asset levels diminishes over time due to depreciation, it affects the overall composition of assets in the total capital stock, leading to historical revisions in capital stock growth rates in some industries. NAS provides tables on the assumed life of assets, and these estimates of lifetime are used to derive depreciation rates for non-ICT assets, using a double declining balance rate, with buildings assumed to have a lifetime of 80 years, transport equipment 20 years, and machinery and equipment 25 years, as per NAS guidelines (CSO, 2007). Capital input is calculated using equation (5.1), requiring estimates of rental prices. Assuming capital service flow is proportional to capital stock at the individual asset level, aggregate capital flows are obtained using a Translog quantity index, weighting growth in each asset's stock by its average share in the value of capital compensation. The rate of return (i) in equation (5.4) is an external rate of return, proxied by the average return on government securities and the prime lending rate obtained from the Reserve Bank of India. A real rate is used.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are some outstanding issues with the measures of capital input available in India KLEMS, and what are some potential solutions or future extensions being considered?
output:
The measures of capital input available in India KLEMS are based on only three asset categories: construction, machinery, and transport equipment. Therefore, it does not consider the enormous and distinct role of ICT capital in contributing to productivity and growth. The absence of ICT estimates in the database is driven by insufficient data on investment in ICT assets, such as hardware, software, and communication equipment in the National Accounts. However, during recent years, NAS has extended its asset coverage to include software and ICT equipment. Erumban and Das (2016) have made some estimates for the aggregate economy using input-output tables for ICT equipment and relying on NAS for software investment. Similarly, Erumban and Das (2020) have made some initial estimates of ICT capital by industries, which still remains a challenging task. Nevertheless, now that more data is available from NAS, it is possible to explore this further, and future extensions of the database may explore this. Similarly, following the SNA 2008 guidelines, the NAS now provides estimates of intangible capital such as intellectual property and research and development (R&D), which may be a useful extension to the capital input database.
Two additional challenges are arising since the new system of national accounts. The first is the lack of separate data on registered and unregistered manufacturing, which poses challenges in using ASI and NSSO data to split aggregate manufacturing data into 13 industry groups. Instead of the registered and unregistered split, CSO now provides a division between the household and corporate sectors. This challenge is currently addressed by considering the household sector as unregistered manufacturing and the sum of public and corporate sectors as a registered sector.
The second challenge is the lack of separate data on transport equipment and machinery assets in the new series of national accounts, which follows United Nation's System of National Accounts (SNA)-2008. Although, for the time being, an ad-hoc approach is adopted to fix this, it cannot be adopted on a long-term basis, which might necessitate combining transport equipment and machinery to one single asset.
Finally, the debate on whether it is appropriate to use an external rate of return or an internal rate of return is unsettled in the literature. It may be worth exploring estimates of capital using the internal rate of return. As mentioned in the context, the present version of the database uses an external rate of return, proxied by average of return on government securities and prime lending rate obtained from the Reserve Bank of India. Therefore, a real rate, which is net of capital gain, is used. Hence, the capital gain component in equation is excluded while estimating rental price using external rate of return, obtaining  𝑃𝑘,𝑡𝐾 = 𝑃𝑘,𝑡−1𝐼 ∙𝑟𝑡 + 𝑃𝑘,𝑡𝐼 ∙𝛿𝑘 (5.4) where r is the real rate of return, nominal interest rate adjusted for consumer price inflation rate and the consumer price indices (CPI) are obtained from IMF and World Bank.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How is the rental price of capital determined, and what factors influence its calculation according to the India KLEMS database?
output: The rental price of capital reflects the price at which an investor is indifferent between buying and renting the capital good for a one-year lease in the rental market.  In the absence of taxation, the rental price equation can be derived as the sum of the nominal rate of return, the nominal cost of depreciation, less capital gain. The formula is: 𝑃𝑘,𝑡𝐾 = 𝑃𝑘,𝑡−1𝐼 ∙𝑖𝑡 + 𝑃𝑘,𝑡𝐼 ∙𝛿𝑘 −(𝑃𝑘,𝑡𝐼 −𝑃𝑘,𝑡−1𝐼 ), where 𝑃𝑘,𝑡𝐼 is the investment price of asset k in year t, and 𝑖𝑡 is the nominal rate of return. The components include the rate of return, depreciation, and capital gain. Therefore, the rental price is determined by the nominal rate of return, economic depreciation costs, and asset-specific capital gains. The rate of return can be measured as internal (ex-post) or external (ex-ante). The India KLEMS database uses an external rate of return, considering prevailing interest rates in the economy, as detailed in section 2.4. While taxes ideally should be included, data limitations preclude this refinement in the database.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What is the basic approach used to derive the volume series of Intermediate Inputs (Energy, Material, and Services) at the industry level, and how are these inputs defined?
output:
In Chapter 6, the basic approach used to derive the volume series of Intermediate Inputs, namely Energy input (E), Material input (M), and Services input (S), is described. The methodology for measuring industry output, intermediate inputs, and value added was developed by Jorgenson, Gallop, and Fraumeni (1987) and extended by Jorgenson (1990 a). The cornerstone of this approach is a time series of input-output (IO) tables which gives the flows of all commodities in the economy, as well as payments to primary factors. Following a similar approach as explained in Jorgenson et al. (2005, Chapter 4) and Timmer et al. (2010, Chapter 3), the time series on intermediate inputs for the India KLEMS project have been constructed.

As in EU KLEMS, this study identifies three main categories of Intermediate inputs:
1. Energy Input, which includes: Coal and Lignite, Petroleum products, Electricity (with the exception of electricity used in the electricity sector, which is treated as material), Natural gas, and Gas (LPG).
2. Material Input
3. Service Input, which includes: Water supply, Railway transport services, Other transport services, Storage and warehousing, Communication, Trade, and Hotels and restaurants.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How are the intermediate inputs classified, and what is the implementation procedure for computing the Intermediate Input Series?
output:
The Intermediate Inputs are classified into three main categories: Energy Input, Material Input, and Service Input. The following five energy types (and products) have been classified as the Energy input: 1. Coal and Lignite 2. Petroleum products 3. Electricity; (for electricity used in the electricity sector, since there is a good amount of inter-firm sale and purchase of electricity, it has been treated as material rather than as energy) 4. Natural gas 5. Gas (LPG). The following fourteen input items have been classified as the Service input: 1. Water supply 2. Railway transport services 3. Other transport services 4. Storage and warehousing 5. Communication 6. Trade 7. Hotels and restaurants 8. Banking 9. Insurance 10. Ownership of dwellings 11. Education and research 12. Medical and health 13. Other services 14. Public administration. All other intermediate inputs barring the above mentioned nineteen inputs are classified as material input.

The methodology for computation of Intermediate Input Series for 27 Industries from 1980- 2023 at current and constant prices is explained in the following steps: Step 1: Concordance is done between IOTT and study industries. The 60/115/130 IOTT industries are aggregated to form industries, and a concordance table between the classification used in our study and each Input Output Transaction Table has been prepared. Step 2: Obtaining estimates for Material, Energy and Service Inputs for 27 Industries, in benchmark years.  In IOTT, no intermediate input is being used in industry 24 – ‘Public Administration’. Consequently, the intermediate input series is being directly estimated for only 26 industries from 1980 to 2023. However, we have used ‘Net Purchase of Commodities and Services’ of Administrative Department as total intermediate input. And using information about ‘Government Final Consumption Expenditure’ we distribute the total intermediate input in to material, energy and services input. The values of Energy Inputs used, Material Inputs used, Service Input used and Total Intermediate Inputs are obtained. Thus, for each of the benchmark year, estimates are obtained for Material, Energy and Service Inputs that has been used to produce Gross output in the 27 different India KLEMS Industries.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How is a time series of proportions of Material, Energy, and Service Inputs in Total Intermediate Inputs projected for each of the 27 industries from 1980 to 2019, and how is consistency with NAS ensured?
output:
A time series (1980 to 2019) of proportions of Material, Energy and Service Inputs in Total Intermediate Inputs for each of the 27 industries is projected as follows:

*   For the Benchmark years i.e., 1978, 1983, 1989, 1993, 1998, 2003, 2007 and 2015 proportions of Material Inputs, Energy Inputs, and Service Inputs in Total Intermediate Inputs are calculated.
*   Similar proportion for intervening years is obtained by linear interpolation of the benchmark proportions.
*   This gives a time series of proportions of Material, Energy and Service Inputs in Total Intermediate Inputs for each year, from 1980 to 2023.
*   Thus, using IOTT, the intermediate input vector has been projected for 27 study industries from 1980 to 2023.

There exists some abnormal fluctuation in the proportions of Material Inputs, Energy Inputs, and Service Inputs in Total Intermediate Inputs for benchmark years. In that case, that specific benchmark proportion is dropped and linearly interpolated with the adjacent benchmark proportions to estimate proportion for intervening years. For the industry ‘Wood & Wood Products’, proportions of Material Inputs, Energy Inputs, and Service Inputs in Total Intermediate Inputs are estimated from SUT 2015-16 instead of Input Output Transaction Table 2015-16.

For the industry group ‘Coke, Refined Petroleum and Nuclear Fuel’, proportions of Material Inputs, Energy Inputs, and Service Inputs in Total Intermediate Inputs are estimated from ASI data instead of Input Output Transaction Table because the relevant proportions differed significantly between the input -out tables and ASI, and the latter is believed to be making a more correct assessment of energy inputs used in the Coke and Petroleum product s industry.

The projection of the intermediate input vector, using IOTT, needs to be consistent with the estimated output from NAS.

*   The Gross Value of Output and the Gross Value Added at current prices calculated from NAS is taken. The difference between GVO and GVA provides us the gap between value added and gross output for each year or in other words this reflects the Total Intermediate inputs from NAS (GVO-GVA).
*   The intermediate input vector that has been projected using IOTT will not tally with the above estimates of Total Intermediate inputs from NAS. Thus, the projected input vector has been proportionately adjusted to match the gap between value added and gross output.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the steps involved in ensuring consistency with the National Accounts Statistics (NAS) when projecting the intermediate input vector using the Input-Output Transaction Table (IOTT), and how are deflators constructed for materials, energy, and service inputs?
output:
The projection of the intermediate input vector, using IOTT needs to be consistent with the estimated output from NAS. This involves two steps:
1.  For Benchmark years: Ratio of Total Intermediate inputs from NAS to that from IOTT is adjusted proportionately to the absolute value of Energy Inputs/Material Inputs/Service Inputs obtained from IOTT.
2.  For Intervening Years: The interpolated proportions of Energy Inputs, Material Inputs and Services Inputs obtained from IOTT, is applied directly to the total intermediate inputs from NAS to get each inputs share.
This gives a time series of Material, Energy, and Service Inputs for 27 study Industries from 1980 to 2023 at current prices.
To compute the Intermediate Input Series for 27 study Industries from 1980 to 2023 at constant price, the approach followed is to first form the aggregates of materials, energy and services at current price for each study industry from the benchmark Input Output tables and then develop deflators of Materials, Energy and Service Inputs for each of the 27 study Industries separately. Deflators are constructed as follows:
• Deflators are obtained for each of the 115 (IOTT 1989 and 1998) and 130 (IOTT 2007) commodity inputs (each row of the IO Matrix).
• WPI for the period 1980 to 2023 is taken from Office of the Economic Adviser, Ministry of Commerce and Industry.
• Best available Wholesale Price Index is applied to each commodity input in the IOTT.
• In several cases, no proper WPI is avail able for the sector; hence the best among the available has been chosen.
• In some cases, the right index has been formed from item level indices.
• In some case, one index has been removed from a higher -level aggregate to generate the right index.
• For Electricity as an input entering into the production process of an industry, depending on the nature of economic activity, the right price of electricity has been chosen. For instance, in the case of manufacturing industries, the price of electricity f or industry considered, similarly for agriculture the price of electricity for agriculture.
• For Service Inputs, since WPI is not available hence implicit GDP deflators from NAS are used.
• Deflators obtained for different IO sectors have been combined using weights. The weights are based on the column of the relevant study industry in the IO table. This is because; the entries read down industry columns give the commodity inputs of raw -materials

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How were the materials, energy, and services series for each industry obtained at current prices, and how were the deflators used to compute time series at constant prices?
output: The materials, energy, and services series for each industry at current prices were obtained using Input-Output (IO) tables. Three IOTTs were used: 1989, 1998, and 2007. The price series based on the 1989 table was used from 1980 to 1993, the 1998 table from 1993 to 2003, and the 2007 table from 2003 to 2023. Once the three series were formed, they were spliced. To compute the time series on intermediate input for 27 study industries from 1980-2023 at constant prices, the deflators for Material, Energy, and Service Inputs for each study industry have been used to deflate the Current price Intermediate Input series to Constant price. For the Agriculture sector the deflated value of intermediate input is adjusted to the gap between value added and gross output at constant price, since Gross Value Added for Agriculture estimated by NAS using double deflated method. Thus, a time series of Material, Energy and Service Inputs for 27 study Industries at constant prices is obtained.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What is the methodology for measuring labor income share series, and why is understanding income distribution important in growth accounting?
output: The distribution of income between capital, labor, and intermediate inputs is an important element in growth accounting because income shares, under conditions of competitive markets, can be used to measure the contributions each factor makes towards output growth. Under the assumption of constant returns to scale with two factors of production (labor and capital), the sum of the labor income share and capital income share is 1. The labor income share is defined as the ratio of labor income to GVA, and the capital income share is accordingly obtained as one minus the labor income share. To compute the labor income share out of value added, one has to take the sum of the compensation of employees and that part of the mixed income which are wages for labor. The computation of labor income share for the 27 study industries involves two steps: First, estimates of CE and MI have to be obtained for each of the 27 study industries from the NAS data which are available only for the NAS sectors (see Table 7.1). Second, the estimate of mixed income has to be split into labor income and capital income for each industry for each year (except for those industries for which the reported mixed income is zero, for instance, public administration).

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What data sources and procedures are used to compute the labor income share and estimate CE, OS, and MI for the 27 study industries?
output:
The computation of labor income share uses NAS, ASI, and unit level data from surveys of unorganized manufacturing enterprises to obtain estimates of CE, OS, and MI for each of the 27 study industries. Unit level data from the NSS employment-unemployment survey are used along with the estimates of CE, OS, and MI from the NAS to split the labor and non-labor components out of the mixed income of self-employed individuals.

The estimation of labor income share for the 27 study industries is done in two steps:

Step 1: Estimation of CE, OS, and MI for the 27 study Industries
NAS provides estimates of compensation of employees (CE), operating surplus (OS) and mixed income (MI) for the 9 NAS industries. For some industries, the required data are readily available from NAS. For others, the estimates available in NAS have to be distributed across the study industries using ASI data. The NAS estimates of factor incomes (CE) for registered manufacturing is split into 13 industries in proportion to the reported ASI data on emoluments for various industries. Estimate of factor incomes for ‘other services’ in NAS has been split into estimates for (i) Education, (ii) Health and Social Work, and (iii) Other Community, Social and Personal Services including Renting of Machinery and Business Services, and Private Household with Employed Persons.

Before 2011-12, NAS provides estimates of factor incomes for registered manufacturing and unregistered manufacturing, but not for individual manufacturing industries. However, 2011-12 onwards NAS disaggregated the manufacturing sector in the corporate sector and household sector. The NAS estimates of factor incomes for registered manufacturing and corporate sector have to be split into various manufacturing industries considered in the study (13 in number) using ASI data. The reported CE in NAS for registered manufacturing and corporate sector has been distributed into those 13 industries in proportion to the reported ASI data on emoluments for various industries. In a similar way, using ASI data, the estimate of OS for registered manufacturing and corporate sector has been distributed. Emoluments are subtracted from gross value added for various industries yielding capital income. The share of different industries in aggregate capital income of organized manufacturing indicated by the ASI data is used to split the estimate of OS for registered manufacturing and corporate sector reported in the NAS.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What methodology is applied for unregistered manufacturing and household sector, and how are the estimates of wage payments used to split the estimate of CE in the NAS for aggregate unregistered manufacturing?
output:
The methodology applied for unregistered manufacturing and household sector is similar to registered manufacturing. The published results and unit level data of survey of unorganized manufacturing industries have been used for this purpose. The estimates of wage payments (to hired workers) in different industries have been used to split (proportionately) the estimate of CE in the NAS for aggregate unregistered manufacturing. The estimated wage payment is subtracted from the estimated value added to obtain an estimate of capital income and mixed income of the self -employed in various unorganized manufacturing industries. The estimate of MI provided in NAS for unregistered manufacturing and household sector has then been proportionately distributed across industries using the estimate of capital income and mixed income of the self-employed in various industries that could be formed on the basis of published results and unit level data of survey of unorganized manufacturing industries.

Unlike the ASI data for organized manufacturing, the data for unorganized manufacturing enterprises are available for only select years. The proportions mentioned above could therefore be computed only for those select years (data for six rounds have been used; these are for 45th Round (1989-90), 51st Round (1994-95), 56th Round (2000-01), 62nd Round (2005-06), 67th round (2010-11) and 73rd Round (2015-16)). It has accordingly, been necessary to resort to interpolation/ extrapolation to obtain the relevant proportions for other years.

As explained above, the income share of labour is computed as: SL it = CE it + ηi × MIit /GVAit … (7.1) In this equation, SL it is the labour income share in industry i in year t, CE it is compensation of employees in industry i in year t, MIit is mixed income of the self-employed persons in industry i in year t, and GVAit is gross value added in industry i in year t. The labour income proportion in income is denoted by η which taken to be a fixed parameter for each industry, not varying over time.

The derivation of the GVA series for different industries has been briefly explained in Chapter 2. The derivation of CE and MI series has been explained in step I above. Therefore, only the estimation method of η needs to be described. The estimation of η has been done with the help of NSS survey-based estimates of employment of different categories of workers (number of persons and days of work) and wage rates (which has been described briefly in chapter 4) coupled with estimates of MI, basically obtained from the NAS. Two approaches have been taken to get an estimate of η, and the labour income share series for different industries finally adopted in the study makes use of an average of the estimates of η obtained by the two approaches.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the two approaches used to estimate the labour income proportion in income (η) when calculating labour income share, and how are they implemented?
output:
There are two approaches to estimate the labour income proportion in income (η). In the first approach, an estimate of labour income of self-employed workers has been made for each study industry for eight years, 1983-84, 1987-88, 1993-94, 1999-00, 2004-05, 2009-10, 2011-12 and 2015-16 on the basis of the estimated number of self-employed, wage rate of self-employed and the number of days of work per week derived from unit records of NSS employment-unemployment survey (major rounds) and PLFS. This annual labour income of self-employed workers is divided by the mixed income of self-employed (derived from NAS) to get an estimate of η. For five industries, the ratio is computed and applied directly. For the other 22 industries, the ratio is computed after clubbing the industries into 11 industry groups, and a common ratio computed for the group is then applied to constituent industries.

In the second approach, the NSS data are used to compute θ, which is the ratio of labour income of self-employed workers to the labour income of regular and casual workers. Then, the estimate of CE provided in the NAS is multiplied by θ to obtain an estimate of the labour income component out of the MI reported in the NAS. The labour component of MI divided by total MI gives an estimate of η. If the estimated labour component of MI exceeds the estimate of MI, the estimate of η is taken as unity.

The average value of η is computed for each industry or industry group by taking the estimates for the years 1983-84, 1987-88, 1993-94, 1999-00, 2004-05, 2009-10, 2011-12 and 2015-16. This is done separately for the estimates based on approach-1 and those based on approach-2.

input: Question: How is the income share of labor, capital, and intermediate inputs in Gross Output computed?
output:
The income share of labor, capital, and intermediate inputs in Gross Output has been computed using the following steps:

•	First, the individual shares of intermediate inputs, that is energy, material, and services in Gross Output, is calculated.
•	The labor income and capital income out of Gross Value Added are further distributed into income share of labor in gross output and income share of capital in gross output.
•	Thus, we get the share of labor, capital, material, energy, and services in output.
•	For the Agriculture Sector, land is taken as an input. First, the income share of intermediate inputs in gross output is calculated. Then the non-labor income (out of value added) in Agriculture is distributed equally between land and capital inputs to derive weights.

7.3. Outstanding Issues
The splitting of unorganized sector factor incomes into individual industries has been done using unorganized survey results. The proportions computed for 1983-84 have been applied for the period 1980-81 to 1983-84. While there were surveys of unorganized manufacturing enterprises in 1978-79, the survey results have not been used for estimation of factor incomes in different industries of the unorganized manufacturing sector.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What is the methodology for measuring total factor productivity (TFP) growth for individual industries in the KLEMS framework?
output:
This chapter deals with the methodology of measurement of total factor productivity (TFP) growth for individual industries in the KLEMS framework and the aggregation from industry level productivity measures to measures for broad sectors and the economy as a whole. The methodology of analysis of sources of gross output growth at the individual industry level and sources of GVA (Gross Value Added) or GDP growth at the broad sector level and economy level will also be presented in this chapter. Our measurement of TFP growth for different industries of the Indian economy is based on a gross output production function for each industry j: Y = f(L(L1, …, Ln), K(K1…Km), E(E1….Es), M(M1 …Mu), S(S1 … Sv ), T), where Y is industry gross output, L is labour input, K is capital input and E, M and S are intermediate inputs-namely energy, material and services and T is an indicator of technology for industry j. All variables are indexed by time (t subscript is suppressed).
There are several things to note about the production function - (1) all variables are aggregates of many components that have been discussed in the earlier report/chapters; (2) we assume that the industry production function is separable in these aggregates; (3) time (indicator of technology) enters the production function symmetrically and directly with inputs. An important feature of the gross output approach is the explicit role of intermediate inputs. In our study, we have considered three intermediate inputs - energy, material and services and this is important as we may find that intermediate inputs are the primary component of some industries outputs. Failure to quantify intermediate inputs leads us to miss both the role of key industries that produce intermediate inputs and the importance of intermediate inputs for the industries that use them. To estimate the contributions of total factor productivity, and inputs to industry level output growth, based on the above-mentioned production function, we construct real values of inputs and output, using industry level price data for capital, labour and intermediate inputs, and output. e.g., PYj; PL j, PK j; PE j. PM j, PS j. The industry price of an input varies across industries.
