output: The National Strategy for Financial Inclusion (NSFI) intended to achieve stability, integrity, and equitable growth through a set of six strategic pillars (Figure I.1) and 18 milestones. The six strategic pillars are Universal Access to Financial Services, Providing Basic Bouquet of Financial Services, Access to Livelihood and Skill Development, Financial Literacy and Education, Customer Protection and Grievance Redressal, and Effective Coordination. NSFI 2019-2024 set forth the vision and key objectives of the financial inclusion policies in India to help expand and sustain the financial inclusion process at the national level through a broad convergence of action involving all the stakeholders in the financial sector. The strategy provided a pathway to accelerate financial inclusion to promote economic wellbeing, prosperity, and sustainable development in the country.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What were some of the key improvements and initiatives undertaken during the five-year period of the National Strategy for Financial Inclusion (NSFI)?
output: During the five-year period of the strategy, the extent of financial inclusion has improved significantly. Some key initiatives included establishing Centres for Financial Literacy (CFL), developing tailored financial literacy modules for key segments by the National Centre for Financial Education (NCFE), setting up/strengthening web portals for grievance redressal, and institutionalizing toll-free helpline numbers by all the financial sector regulators. The total number of banking outlets in villages increased from 5.97 lakh in March 2019 to 15.98 lakh in March 2024. Similarly, the total number of basic savings bank deposit accounts increased from 57.42 crore in March 2019 to 70.59 crore in March 2024. Enrollment in Pradhan Mantri Jeevan Jyoti Bima Yojana (PMJJBY) improved from 5.34 crore in March 2019 to 16 crores in March 2024, with a CAGR of 25 percent. Enrollment in Pradhan Mantri Suraksha Bima Yojana (PMSBY) improved from 13.52 crore to 33.78 crore during the period, with a CAGR of 20 percent. The cumulative number of subscribers to Atal Pension Yojana (APY) grew at a CAGR of 42 percent from 97 lakh to 555 lakhs during the period of strategy. Furthermore, the Reserve Bank launched two specific indices viz. Digital Payments Index (DPI) and Financial Inclusion Index (FI -Index) in 2021, to capture the extent of digitalization of payments and assess the level of financial inclusion across the country, respectively. The DPI, which stood at 153.47 in March 2019, has risen to 445.50 in March 2024. The FI-Index has improved from 49.9 in 2019 to 64.2 in 2024, with Access sub-index improving from 67.5 in 2019 to 79.3 in 2024, usage sub-index improving from 38.7 in 2019 to 55.5 in 2024 and quality sub -index improving from 52.6 in 2019 to 65.8 in 2024.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What role did the Financial Inclusion (FI) Ecosystem play during the COVID-19 Pandemic?
output:
The COVID-19 pandemic induced an unforeseen global socio-economic distress and caused loss of lives and livelihood with substantial spill overs. This created an extraordinary challenge for the governments and policymakers to implement appropriate relief, restoration, and stimulus package to minimise and absorb the pandemic induced hardships.

Government of India, State Governments, Reserve Bank of India and other relevant stakeholders took numerous steps to leverage the last mile reach of the FI ecosystem and digital transactions in furthering and deepening the financial inclusion efforts, especially through Digital Public Infrastructures (DPI) in a cost-effective and innovative manner. To mitigate the adverse impact of COVID-19 pandemic, the Government of India was able to smoothly deliver an amount of ₹5.53 lakh crore digitally across 319 government schemes spread over 54 ministries during 2020-21 under the PM Garib Kalyan Yojana, using DPI.

The Business Correspondent (BC) Model emerged as a critical lifeline in disbursing such benefits to the doorstep of the people, especially in rural areas of the country. During the pandemic, ICT-BC transaction routed through BC outlets witnessed a significant surge crossing more than 94 crore transactions accounting for ₹2.25 lakh crore during 2020-21.

RBI in its pursuit to support digital financial services enhanced limit for additional factor of authentication (AFA) per transaction for card transactions in contactless mode at Points of Sale (PoS) terminals , while actively promoting use of digital payments . Further, to alleviate stress amongst small borrowers, RBI undertook measures, namely, grant of moratorium on consumer term loan for a period of six months (March 1, 2020 – August 31, 2020), deferment of interest on working capital facilities in the form of cash credit/overdraft, easing of working capital financing , and facilitating financial institutions to resolve stressed loans to individuals, small business and MSMEs, besides several relaxations in priority sector lending.

Since the pandemic created hurdles in delivering financial literacy to the masses through physical modes, Regional Offices (ROs) of the Bank explored innovative approaches to promote financial literacy amongst the masses, such as Community Radio Channels, Local TV Channels and Local FM stations to impart the financial education in regional languages/local dialects. On its part, SEBI adopted virtual mode to reach out to investors across the country covering over one lakh participants through investor awareness programmes conducted by exchanges, depositories, and SEBI recognised investor associations and trainers.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the supply and demand side impediments to financial inclusion?
output: Financial inclusion initiatives start from the supply side of financial services whereby the availability of financial services in terms of access points, products, etc. is ensured. Availability of adequate supply infrastructure for financial services in terms of well-functioning access points, physical or digital interfaces, suitable products, and services, etc., is necessary though not a sufficient condition for effective financial inclusion, as demand for financial services also plays a crucial role in effectiveness of financial inclusion initiatives. Hence, both supply and demand aspects of financial inclusion should be paid adequate attention to, while formulating financial inclusion strategies. Amongst the key supply side challenges, the quality and effectiveness of last mile reach to the financial services remains the most important element. On the other hand, demand side issues are conditioned by several factors in the usage and quality dimension of financial inclusion. The first set of challenges to the demand for financial services stem from information asymmetry, lack of proper knowhow about availability, cost, and use of financial services, and at times, inability to understand and comprehend the information due to language or literacy barriers. Secondly, behavioural factors, such as personality traits, experiential factors, bounded rationality, and impulsive actions also play a role in catalyzing or dampening the usage of financial services. Behaviourally, the perceived need for financial services, and trust in the system are the two most crucial determinants of the demand side of financial inclusion. If people trust that it is in their benefit to use formal financial services, they will seek access and ensure usage, provided the services are suitably and conveniently made available in an affordable manner. Another critical demand-side impediment to financial inclusion falls in the domain of financial constraints, which either sway away people from the banking system or their usage remains very low. The effectiveness of customer protection and grievance redressal measures remains at the core of the demand for financial services, especially for the underprivileged and vulnerable segments of the population. Moreover, the ecosystem gaps, namely, inefficient , or broken linkages between various initiatives , and gaps in market access coupled with funding constraints could dampen the demand side of financial inclusion.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the key requirements for successful financial inclusion initiatives, and how does the National Strategy for Financial Inclusion (NSFI: 2019-24) address the need for periodic evaluation and insights from both financial service providers and customers?
output: The success in financial inclusion initiatives requires multi-stakeholder contribution in all its dimensions, namely, access, usage, and quality. To be effective, financial inclusion policies should focus on strengthening supply initiatives in the financial sector in terms of easy and trustworthy availability of access points, minimum cost of services, suitable products, financial literacy and proper flow of information, and an effective grievance redressal mechanism. They should also adequately focus on understanding and mitigating demand side impediments and improving the enablers in both supply and demand dimensions. The National Strategy for Financial Inclusion (NSFI: 2019-24) highlighted the need for periodic evaluation of the state of financial inclusion through monitoring of financial inclusion parameters to provide policy makers and stakeholders with necessary insights to understand the achievements made and to address issues and challenges through a coordinated approach. NSFI also underlined that in addition to data collected from financial service providers (supply-side data), there is also a need to seek views and insights from the customers (demand -side insights) at periodic intervals. Accordingly, specific studies and surveys were undertaken by the Reserve Bank to understand the ground level issues and impediments, in both demand and supply dimensions.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What were the key findings regarding the last mile reach of financial services by Business Correspondents (BCs) from the all-India survey conducted by the Bank during January-March 2024?
output:
An assessment of supply side impediments, especially from the angle of last mile access, reveals that the last mile reach of financial services being carried out by business correspondents (BC) requires improvements. The all-India survey conducted by the Bank on the operations of BCs during January-March 2024 highlighted the following areas of concern:

a. There is a need for improvement in the representation of women in the BC agents.
b. Remittances and cash in/out are the most commonly provided services by BC outlets, but other services like insurance, micro-pension, loans are not uniformly available.
c. There is a lack of standardization in the services offered by BCs.
d. The BC ecosystem is marred by a significant proportion of inactive and/or closed BC outlets, and their distribution is skewed.
e. Insufficient and lack of timely remuneration was observed as a major reason for inactivity.
f. Several BC outlets/agents were simultaneously working for multiple banks thereby leading to accountability vacuum from the point of view of customer service.
g. The survey showed that a majority of BCs did not display fees levied for services.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the demand and supply side impediments and challenges to financial inclusion?
output: An assessment of supply side impediments, especially from the angle of last mile access reveals that the last mile reach of financial services being carried out by business correspondents (BC) requires improvements. An all -India survey was conducted by the Bank on the operations of BCs during January-March 2024 through its Regional Offices across the country. About 63% of BCs covered by the survey were in rural areas, 23% in semi-urban areas, and 14% in urban areas. The survey covering 13274 BC outlets in 31 States/UTs involving 154 districts with a greater weightage to aspirational districts, revealed several areas of concerns, which require corrective measures, including the presence of a significant number of non-dedicated outlets in the BC ecosystem, a lack of standardization in the services offered by BCs, a skewed distribution of BCs in many places, insufficient and lack of timely remuneration, agents simultaneously working for multiple banks, and a majority of BCs not displaying fees levied for services. In addition, a lack of a standardised mandatory transaction confirmation SMS or audio-based confirmation, the quality of services rendered by BC outlets, service quality impacted by connectivity issues, operational difficulties, limited inter -operability, and unscrupulous practices also contribute to impediments. To assess the demand side impediments to financial inclusion at a disaggregated level with demographic details, an all-India survey was conducted during March-April 2024 with 9,147 respondents spread across 34 States/Union Territories of the country. Key observations of the survey include a key demand side impediment to account ownership/usage being lack of source of deposit to bank account, and besides income, a preference for cash, lack of knowledge, or family members having an account emerged as common impediments to bank account ownership and usage for relatively lower income groups.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the key observations regarding the demand side impediments to financial inclusion based on the all-India survey conducted during March-April 2024?
output:
Based on an all-India survey conducted during March-April 2024, the following key observations were made regarding demand side impediments to financial inclusion:

(c) Non-usage of bank accounts due to lack of regular source of deposit was more dominant for male respondents and was more pronounced in other than semi-urban areas. In case of semi-urban areas, banking fee/charges were reported as major impediments. People’s trust in banks to save money was more pronounced in rural areas. The level of education helped in strengthening trust and retaining customer relationship in the formal financial system. Generally, people with lower education were relatively unable or unwilling to save through banking channels.

(d) Usage of BC outlets was higher in rural/semi-urban areas as compared to urban areas, especially for female respondents vis-à-vis male respondents. The study shows that as one moves up the hierarchy in terms of income and education levels, the preference for transacting through branch or BC mode diminishes and preference for digital transactions enhances. However, transactions at ATMs seem to be not impacted by income or education levels. Hence, income and education emerge as a couple of key demand side determinants of the choice of access points and mode of transactions.

(e) Preference for digital transactions was seen conditioned by gender, education, and income levels. Male respondents and people form higher income groups had higher preference for digital transactions. Having a smartphone did not necessarily translate as a fillip for digital transactions as several respondents felt dissuaded from undertaking digital transactions due to connectivity issues, complex interfaces, language barrier and concerns regarding breach of OTP/PIN, etc.

(a) In the household segment, personal loans, education loans, and home loans were the top three credit facilities in demand, yet about 50 percent of aspirants had unmet credit needs. Lack of awareness about the procedure, unavailability of nearby bank branch, and lack of collateral were cited as top three impediments in that order, for inability to get credit. Interestingly, high cost (interest rate) of credit was the least cited impediment.

(b) Around 16 per cent of the respondents used informal sources of credit mostly for small ticket loans, with its share being higher in rural areas. In general, people may have relied upon informal sources of credit due to ease, timeliness, and convenient access.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the key enablers for better usage of insurance and pension facilities, and how do female respondents compare to their male counterparts in accessing these facilities, according to the survey?
output: Income and education levels emerged as key enablers for better usage of insurance and pension facilities. While female respondents lagged their male counterparts in access to life insurance, they had an edge in non-life insurance, indicating a possibility of gradually increasing asset ownership by females. Among the respondents who did not have any insurance/pension product, the awareness about the need for insurance and pension products was found to be low. In general, awareness about schemes like PMSBY, PMJJBY, PMFBY, and APY ranged between 30-35%. However, the respondents who knew some beneficiary of insurance claim were generally more likely to opt for it.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are some key observations regarding customer satisfaction and the objectives of NSFI: 2025-30?
output: Customer satisfaction feedback may not be properly anchored to its underlying parameters, such as the complaint process. NSFI: 2025-30 leverages the gains and progress made during the period of previous strategy and strives to put in place a strategic vision and pathway to mitigate demand and supply impediments while further deepening and strengthening the financial inclusion ecosystem.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What is the vision of NSFI (2025-30) regarding financial inclusion and its broader impact?
output: The vision of NSFI (2025-30) is to create an inclusive financial system towards the wellbeing of people. Financial inclusion initiatives generally begin with supply initiatives to provide affordable, easy, trusted, and fair access to regulated financial services, namely, savings, payments, investments, credit, remittances, insurance, and pension to hitherto excluded and marginalized segments of society. Though financial inclusion falls within the ambit of the financial sector, financial inclusion policies have far and wide positive impacts and correlations in the socioeconomic domain. Financial inclusion is referenced in the targets of eight out of the seventeen United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), namely, SDG-1 on eradicating poverty, SDG-2 on ending hunger, achieving food security, and promoting sustainable agriculture, SDG-3 on promoting health and well-being, SDG-5 on achieving gender equality and economic empowerment of women, SDG-8 on promoting economic growth and jobs, SDG-9 on supporting industry, innovation and infrastructure, SDG-10 on reducing inequality, and SDG-17 on strengthening the means of implementation. Financial inclusion being an aspirational journey starts from creating opportunities for access to the formal financial system for the hitherto excluded and underserved segments, but its mandate goes beyond access to ensure effective usage of financial services to the benefit of people. Effective usage requires that people have an economic case for using the formal financial services which primarily comes from their capacity to have regular income/cash flow through employment, livelihood, etc., and have a perceptible economic incentive for using formal financial services. The sustenance and growth of usage also require continued trust of the people, suitability of products and services, sound financial literacy, a pro-active/quick grievance redressal mechanism, and a positive perception of being heard, which are some of the quality aspects of financial inclusion. Seen in the above context and in accordance with the role of financial inclusion in the achievement of sustainable development goals, it is obvious that financial inclusion is not just an end in itself but a means to a greater end of ensuring the overall wellbeing of people.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How do Financial Inclusion (FI) policies contribute to achieving specific Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and their targets?
output:
Financial Inclusion (FI) policies play a significant role in achieving various Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and their targets. According to Table III.1, they contribute in the following ways:

*   **SDG 1: Poverty Reduction:** FI improves access to financial services and skilling/livelihood opportunities, enhancing income sustenance, sufficiency, and safety, thus reducing poverty.
*   **SDG 2: Ending Hunger:** An inclusive financial system incentivizes credit-led investments for sustainable and productivity-enhancing agricultural practices, resulting in better agricultural yields and enhanced food security, thereby helping in reducing hunger.
*   **SDG 3: Health and Wellbeing:** FI, through its multi-faceted socio-economic dimensions, aids human development and augments the resilience of marginalized and vulnerable populations, fostering health and well-being.
*   **SDG 5: Gender Equality:** Gender-sensitive FI policies decrease gender inequality by empowering women and improving their overall socio-economic status.
*   **SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth:** FI, with its ecosystem approach, supports economic growth by providing necessary funding, augmenting employment and entrepreneurship, and boosting consumption.
*   **SDG 9: Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure:** FI policies support the industry, especially micro and small enterprises, by providing credit linkages and digital infrastructure for promoting innovation and boosting their progress.
*   **SDG 10: Reducing Inequalities:** FI policies, with their specific focus on the upliftment of the poor, marginalized, and vulnerable segments, and the last mile reach, help to reduce inequalities.
*   **SDG 17: Strengthening the means of Implementation:** FI is an important means of implementation for achieving SDGs, through the mobilization of savings/investments, boosting consumption, and improving the overall wellbeing of people, which can help in achieving broader developmental goals.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How is financial inclusion defined and what are its aims according to various committees and the NSFI?
output: The Committee on Financial Inclusion (Chairman: Dr C Rangarajan, RBI, 2008) defined financial inclusion as “the process of ensuring access to financial services, timely and adequate credit for vulnerable groups such as weaker sections and low -income groups at an affordable cost”. Further, the Committee on Medium -Term Path to Financial Inclusion (Chairman: Shri Deepak Mohanty, RBI, 2015) viewed financial inclusion as, “convenient access to a basket of basic formal financial products and services that should include savings, remittance, credit, government -supported insurance and pension products to small and marginal farmers and low income households at reasonable cost with adequate protection progressively supplemented by social cash transfers, besides increasing the access of small and marginal enterprises to formal finance with a greater reliance on technology to cut costs and improve service delivery.” The NSFI (2019 -24) aimed at broadening, deepening, and accelerating financial inclusion alongside promoting financial literacy and consumer protection, with a view to promoting economic wellbeing, prosperity, and sustainable development. Continuing the journey and leveraging the substantial gains during the last decade in the bank account ownership to near saturation, robust expansion in physical and digital access infrastructure, and improvements in customer awareness and protection measures, it is desirable to upscale the focus of financial inclusion by adopting a synergistic ecosystem approach . This would ensure integrated and seamless involvement of stakeholders for developing a truly inclusive financial system towards wellbeing of people by minimization of inequality of opportunities for people to reap the benefits of access to formal financial system, while substantially improving the quality and consistency of last mile reach. Financial inclusion policies duly integrated with livelihood support, market linkages, financial education, and customer protection initiatives are great enablers of an improved state of the economic wellbeing of people. Pursued holistically, financial inclusion can lead to desirable outcomes in form of a quadrangle of financial safety, financial security, financial resilience, and financial discipline, in turn contributing towards overall wellbeing of people.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the objectives and intended outcomes of financial inclusion under NSFI: 2025-30, and how does financial inclusion improve the financial well-being of individuals and micro-enterprises?
output: The objectives and intended outcome of financial inclusion to be pursued under NSFI: 2025 -30 are presented below. The objective of financial inclusion is ensuring availability of equitable, responsible, suitable, and affordable access to a bouquet of formal financial services, namely, savings, payments, remittances, credit, investments, insurance, and pension, across socio-economic and geographical strata, coupled with effective financial literacy, robust consumer awareness and customer protection measures. Financial inclusion, as above, with the involvement of all stakeholders improves financial safety, financial security, financial resilience, and financial discipline of individuals (households) and micro-enterprises.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What does equitable, responsible, suitable and affordable access to a bouquet of formal financial services mean in the context of financial inclusion?
output: Equitable access means the access infrastructure should be available across the geographic strata in a reasonably homogeneous manner. Responsible means the financial service providers should ensure that their products/ services do not manipulate or impede customers’ free choices, interests, and right to product suitability, and do not leave customers’ worse off in terms of the economic, behavioural, and social outcomes. Suitable means financial products and services should be appropriate to customers need and based on customers’ financial circumstances and understanding. Differentiated/customised services should be available to enable people to choose what is best for them. Affordable means the basic minimum financial services (basic transaction account, basic savings and investment account, small value remittances, small value digital payments, etc.) should be offered free of cost. Pricing of other services should have an essential element of affordability keeping in mind the marginal cost of services.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the anchors and explanatory details related to financial resilience and financial discipline as outcomes of financial inclusion?
output: Financial Resilience refers to the “Ability to recover from financial setbacks” and is anchored by Insurance Coverage, which includes unexpired insurance coverage within acceptable/bearable cost – life coverage, health coverage, asset coverage (vehicles/property/machines, etc.), and Credit Facilities, which includes fair Emergency Credit to reasonably cope with a financial setback/sudden difficult situation such as, loss of life/ livelihood/assets without excessive debt burden or losses impeding day-to-day life. Financial Discipline refers to “Attitude and behaviour towards a steady financial future” and is anchored by Financial Education, which includes Financial Awareness and Confidence, Experiential Learning, Diversified Investments - Distributing savings /investments across different banks/asset classes, Sustainable Indebtedness - monthly repayment amount towards outstanding loans not exceeding half of the monthly income of the household, and Realistic Goal Setting and Planning - Making financial goals within one’s means, and planning for future expenses/ life -events (education/ marriage of children, retirement, etc.).

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What is the vision of the National Strategy for Financial Inclusion (NSFI) as of 2025-30?
output: The vision of NSFI (2025-30) is to strengthen the financial inclusion ecosystem with the synergised efforts of stakeholders towards wellbeing of people by ensuring delivery of equitable, responsible, suitable, and affordable financial services duly supported by livelihood enablers, effective financial literacy, digital public infrastructure, and robust customer protection. The current iteration of the National Strategy for Financial Inclusion for the period 2025-30 (NSFI: 2025 -30) is an outcome of wide -ranging stakeholder consultations. The strategy is informed of the achievements of the NSFI 2019 -24 and focusses on further deepening, sustaining, and synergising financial inclusion initiatives.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the strategic objectives and action points of the National Strategy for Financial Inclusion (NSFI) 2025-30, and how do they align with the global Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)?
output:
The National Strategy for Financial Inclusion (NSFI) intends to achieve integrated, seamless, and synergised working of stakeholders of the Financial Inclusion (FI) ecosystem to augment the effectiveness of financial inclusion policies through the availability and use of equitable, responsible, and affordable financial services along with skilling/livelihood opportunities, duly supported by Digital Public Infrastructure, effective financial literacy, robust consumer awareness and protection measures.

The timeline of NSFI: 2025-30 is synchronized with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. India’s contribution is critical to the global achievement of SDGs, and the strategy intends to meet the national priorities and assist in the achievement of targets as a part of the transformative agenda. NSFI’s ecosystem approach as discussed in Chapter -III bodes well with the SDG’s philosophy, namely, coordinated efforts by all the stakeholders to achieve the developmental agenda of leaving no one behind, seeking participation of everyone - everywhere, especially the vulnerable and marginalised.

NSFI: 2025-30 sets up the following five strategic and synergised objectives towards well-being of people.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the five strategic objectives of the National Strategy for Financial Inclusion (NSFI) 2025-30, also known as Panch-Jyoti?
output:
The five strategic objectives of the National Strategy for Financial Inclusion (NSFI) 2025-30 (Panch-Jyoti) are:

I. Improving the availability and use of Equitable, Responsible, Suitable, and Affordable Bouquet of Financial Services to achieve Financial Safety and Financial Security for households and micro enterprises.

II. Adopting Gender-Sensitive Approach for Women-led Financial Inclusion and Differentiated Strategies for Improving Financial Resilience of Households, especially for the Underserved and Vulnerable segments.

III. Synergizing Livelihood, Skill Development and Support Ecosystem and its linkages with Financial Inclusion.

IV. Leveraging Financial Education as a tool for promoting Financial Discipline.

V. Strengthening the Quality and Reliability of Customer Protection and Grievance Redressal Measures. These objectives aim to elevate the state of financial inclusion in the country.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What recommendations and action points are there for improving the equity, reach, consistency, and quality of last mile access to financial services under the National Strategy for Financial Inclusion (NSFI)?
output:
Digital financial services operating on the backbone of Digital Public Infrastructure (DPI) have provided a significant fillip to financial inclusion initiatives across a wide spectrum ranging from account ownership, social benefit transfers, quicker and efficient remittances/payments, and access to credit. DPI, as interoperable, open, and inclusive systems supported by technology, serves to provide essential public and private services for the common good. The India Stack exemplifies this approach, combining digital ID, interoperable payments, a digital credentials ledger, and account aggregation framework. By leveraging the gains made, there is scope for further expanding the digital footprints for discharge of a range of financial services.

It is recommended to improve the equity, reach, consistency, and quality of last mile access by strengthening the network of business correspondents and expanding the delivery of safe and cost-effective digital financial services at the last mile.

To bring about substantial improvements in the equity, reach, consistency, and quality of last mile access to financial services, there is a need to ensure availability of at least one banking outlet – branch /digital banking unit (DBU)/ fixed point business correspondent outlet (FBC) working for a minimum of 4 hours per day for at least five days a week in each revenue centre, so that financial services are fairly and equitably available across the depth and breadth of the country. A revenue Centre is defined as the revenue unit classified and delineated by the respective State Government, i.e., a revenue village/ city/ town/ municipality/ municipal corporation, etc., as the case may be. Based on the size of the population, a revenue centre is classified into rural (population less than 10,000), semi-urban (10,000 and above and less than 1 lakh), urban (1 lakh and above and less than 10 lakhs), or metropolitan (10 lakhs and above). Such outlets, under adequate control and oversight of banks, are expected to provide a range of financial services.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What actions should SLBCs/UTLBCs take to improve universal access to financial services, and how can the availability and consistency of last mile access in hilly and rural areas be improved, including remuneration structures for BC agents?
output:
SLBCs/UTLBCs should put in place an action plan and allocate goals to banks in a phased manner to achieve the action point during the period of the strategy, with suitable mid-term goals. This will support the minimum standard set of financial services, namely, deposits, withdrawals, remittances, account opening and servicing, Jan Suraksha Schemes, loan leads/applications, pension schemes, etc., building on the progress where access to some form of banking services has been provided to 99.9 per cent of the targeted villages within 5 KM radius/ hamlets with 500 households in hilly areas.

To improve the availability and consistency of last mile access in hilly and rural areas, especially given inadequacies of bank branches in the north eastern (NE)/ hilly states, and rural areas where banking services are mostly dependent upon the BC outlets, the existing scheme of incentives, under Financial Inclusion Fund (FIF), to BCs operating in Tier V & Tier VI centres in NE States and other Hilly States /UTs (Himachal Pradesh, Jammu & Kashmir, Ladakh & Uttarakhand) may be extended in a calibrated manner to all Fixed-Point BCs operating in Tier VI centres. This addresses the fact that the distribution of FBCs, especially in the NE region is skewed with only 165 FBCs per thousand square kilometres vis -à-vis 379 FBCs per thousand square kilometres at the national level. Furthermore, to ensure quality and consistency in delivery of financial services at the last mile, fair and reasonable remuneration structure for BC agents is a must.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are some recommendations for improving the sustenance of BC operations and expanding digital financial services?
output: To ensure quality and consistency in delivery of financial services at the last mile, a fair remuneration structure of BC agents relating to banking products and services may be worked out under the aegis of Indian Banks Association (IBA). To augment the scope of services offered by Fixed-Point BCs and to improve their sustenance in terms of earning potential, financial services providers should consider offering additional/value-added services through well-functioning BCs, based on an objective and transparent performance criterion, while meeting regulatory norms. The network of well-functioning FBCs may be leveraged for offering additional basic financial services, namely, basic mutual fund, pension and insurance products and related services, subject to meeting requisite criteria and regulatory norms. The existing BC registry portal being maintained by IBA provides a dynamic and comprehensive dataset to monitor the operations of BCs with a view to ensuring quality and last mile reach, and IBA should further strengthen and develop additional capabilities in the registry portal to improve periodic updation of the data, location mapping, de-duplication, certification status, etc. In order to expand digital financial services, the goal of reaching one billion users in digital payments ecosystem by December 2029 may guide further efforts in expanding the reach of such payment modes, since UPI recorded nearly 16.7 billion transactions during the month of December 2024, and there were 424 million unique UPI users in June 2024.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the goals and initiatives related to expanding digital payments, utilizing programmable CBDC, and developing a Unified Lending Interface (ULI)?
output: The initiatives include: (b) Expanding and Deepening Digital Payment Ecosystem (EDDPE) programme, which aims at providing every eligible individual in identified districts at least one mode of digital payments namely, debit/rupay cards, net banking, mobile banking, UPI, USSD, AEPS etc., is underway with goals to achieve 100% coverage in 80% of districts by March 2026, and 100% coverage in all identified districts by March 2027. (c) Programmable CBDC to Facilitate Targeted Credit Flow and Expand Access: Programmability feature in Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC) could help in tying up the end use, for example, agriculture credit by banks using CBDC can be programmed to ensure its use only at input store outlets. Similarly, for MSMEs etc., programmability may take care of the issue of diversion of funds and ensure optimum utilisation. Programmable CBDC may be leveraged to facilitate credit flow to underserved segments like tenant farmers, micro enterprises, etc., by conducting pilots of programmable CBDC across various borrower segments. Offline functionality in use cases may also be explored to make CBDC accessible to individuals in areas with limited or no connectivity. (d) Unified Lending Interface (ULI): Unified Lending Interface (ULI), as a DPI, has been conceptualised to enable delivery of frictionless credit by facilitating seamless flow of required digital information to lenders through conduct of pilots on various loan journeys, while onboarding of more and more lenders and data service providers. ULI may be rolled out in a phased manner.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What actions should be taken regarding the Jansuraksha Portal and Atal Pension Yojana (APY) to improve social security and pension coverage?
output: All banks and insurance companies should be onboarded to the Jansuraksha portal to provide a seamless digital journey for subscribers for enrolments, issuance of policy certificates, and claims processing. The Jansuraksha portal provides access to Social Security Insurance Schemes introduced by the Government of India, serving as an end-to-end portal for enrolments and claims under Pradhan Mantri Suraksha Bima Yojana (PMSBY) and Pradhan Mantri Jeevan Jyoti Bima Yojana (PMJJBY). Improved efficiency and transparency of transactions through the portal would augment trust in the schemes and help increase the coverage level in a systematic manner. Additionally, sectoral regulators and Financial Service Providers (FSPs) should make concerted efforts to improve the coverage of Atal Pension Yojana (APY) by strengthening its distribution network and creating awareness.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What roles should Self-Regulatory Organizations (SROs) play in promoting financial inclusion, and what approach should be adopted for women-led financial inclusion and improving the financial resilience of underserved segments?
output: Self-Regulatory Organisations (SRO) in the fintech sector (SRO-FT), microfinance sector and other domains may endeavor to promote the extension of responsible, suitable, and affordable financial products/services and adoption of financial inclusion policies by their member entities, by incorporating suitable provisions in the code of conduct for members. Adoption of a gender sensitive approach is needed to augment and promote women agency in the FI ecosystem to take advantage of women-led financial inclusion and extension initiatives. Financial inclusion policies must facilitate a differentiated approach towards suitable customization and delivery of financial products and services in accordance with the needs and preferences of the end-users. Adoption of a gender sensitive approach is recommended to strengthen women led financial inclusion and extension initiatives for the improved outcomes, besides following a differentiated approach towards delivery of financial services for underserved and vulnerable segments. There is a need to promote and encourage women as facilitators of financial services by increasing their numbers as business correspondent agents.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the recommendations for increasing women's participation as business correspondents and providing financial services to vulnerable segments?
output: The goal is to ensure at least 30% share of women BCs in the medium term from the current level of around 15%. SLBCs/UTLBCs should put in place a voluntary action plan adopted by member banks to deploy women as business correspondents in a phased manner to achieve the milestone by December 2028. With a view to providing suitable and timely financial services to the underserved and vulnerable segments, there is a need to develop suitable markers/matrix to be followed by financial services providers in dealing with such customers. Accordingly, financial sector regulators may develop an identification matrix both based on a combination of categorical and circumstantial factors. Going beyond the approach of offering low -cost universal financial products and services to promote financial inclusion, there is a need to focus on product suitability and personal suitability, especially for underserved and vulnerable segments. Accordingly, financial services providers should develop suitable basket of products (such as, basic MF products, calamity insurance, etc.) to meet the requirements of such segments. Financial sector regulators may appropriately mandate the development of such products. To strengthen financial security and financial resilience of people, suitable bundled products may be developed in the investment, pension, and insurance domains (e.g., a single insurance product offering life, health, accident, and property cover). To strengthen financial resilience of people, suitable and fair credit products with easier documentation process and quick disbursals should be launched especially for small ticket loans to prevent people from having to access informal sources of finance/ unauthorized digital lenders, etc. for small and urgent credit requirements.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What measures can be taken to further strengthen financial inclusion and improve income-earning capabilities?
output: To further strengthen the institutional means for provision of fair and easy emergency credit, an overdraft facility charged at a reasonable interest rate may be made a default product feature in all Aadhar-seeded BSBD Accounts (to avoid duplication) after regular operation of the account for at least six months. Furthermore, leveraging Skill India Digital Hub and local community organizations is recommended for augmenting synergy and convergence in the skilling and livelihood ecosystem to plug gaps in credit/market linkages and mitigate demographic/geographic inequalities to improve employability and entrepreneurial opportunities, facilitating better income-earning capabilities, which in turn leads to effective access and usage of financial services. Additionally, ensuring at least 30% share of women BCs in the medium term from the current level, with SLBCs/UTLBCs implementing voluntary action plans to achieve this milestone by December 2028, and focusing on product suitability and personal suitability for underserved and vulnerable segments by developing a suitable basket of products (such as basic MF products, calamity insurance, etc.) to meet the requirements of such segments can further strengthen financial inclusion.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the key action points for skill training content development, data sharing, reporting, funding, and financial support for skill-trained individuals, as outlined by NSDC and other governmental bodies?
output:
The action points are as follows:

1.  Content Development and Delivery for Skill Training:

(a) NSDC may act as the nodal agency for developing content and arranging skill training across the skilling and livelihood ecosystem. New content development and/or updation of existing content on financial literacy included in the skill development programme may be undertaken in consultation with NCFE.

(b) NSDC may steer the adoption of the National Skills Qualifications Framework (NSQF) by all skill training institutions to enable individuals to acquire desired competency levels, to enhance employability potential. Skill training curriculum should be made available in all scheduled languages on the Skill India Digital Hub and be readily accessible to all.

(c) NSDC may lead the efforts to synergize the resources of all skill training entities (RSETIs, JSS, PMKVY, NISEBUD, Skill India Centers, ITIs, Skill and Vocational Colleges, etc.) through onboarding and data sharing on the Skill India Digital Hub. A gender-sensitive approach may be adopted by all the skilling and livelihood institutions to help in achieving the national target under SDG-2030 (SDG-5).

2.  Data Sharing and Reporting:

NSDC may leverage Skill India Digital Hub to collate and publish periodic reports on numbers and types of skill training conducted by various skilling/training entities and their settlement. Skilling and settlement initiatives under other Government programmes such as NRLM and NULM, including financial literacy focused training for SHG members, may be integrated into the database in due course, to have complete pan-India data on the skilling and livelihood ecosystem.

3.  Funding and Financial Support to Skill Trained Individuals:

(a) Information on skill loan schemes of NSDC, Government of India and State Governments may be made available widely, including by participating financial sector entities, to encourage individuals to enroll for suitable skill training with financial support.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What measures should be taken to support individuals trained by recognized skill training institutions and how can local community organizations contribute to creating synergy in the financial inclusion ecosystem?
output:
Potential Linked Plans (PLP) of each district under respective State/UTs should have a suitable allocation for the individuals trained by recognised skill training institutions (R-SETIs, PMKVY, JSS etc.) to enable credit support to such individuals by banks. Trained candidates must be provided with the necessary support through handholding arrangements in approaching financial institutions for credit facilities.
To involve local communities for social intermediation by way of a structured mechanism to synergise the efforts made by various stakeholders through a trusted-assisted middle layer of social infrastructure in form of Community Resource Entities (CREs). CREs refer to locally rooted community organizations, such as cooperatives, trusts/societies, and NGOs, that would provide social intermediation within skilling for livelihood ecosystem.
The purpose of CREs is to create synergy in the financial inclusion ecosystem by offering community-oriented intermediation and localized support for facilitating access to skilling/livelihood, market linkages, and bank credit. It would create a trusted-assisted middle layer in form of a social infrastructure to undertake the following functions:
a. Assessment of training gap - CREs will collect data of unemployed, underemployed, school dropouts and other in need for skill training via survey or through participatory identification process.
b. Liaison with skill training entities – CREs should have appropriate linkages with relevant skill training agencies, potential employers, and banks.
c. CREs should map training needs of the locality with respective skill development institutions.
d. Handholding of trained individuals after completion of training and providing support for employment/entrepreneurship and funding.
CREs being locally rooted will have the capacity to mobilize individuals and gain the trust of the local communities. By engaging with the community, CREs would act as a bridge between the skilling centers, banks, and livelihood providers/ employers on one end, and aspirants on the other end, thereby providing a broader spectrum of forward and backward linkages while reducing information asymmetry in the FI ecosystem.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the action points for leveraging financial education as a tool for promoting financial discipline?
output:
The action points for leveraging financial education as a tool for promoting financial discipline are:

1.  Sustaining and deepening financial literacy initiatives through constant policy review of dissemination channels such as Centres of Financial Literacy (CFL) and Financial Literacy Centres (FLCs) along with supplementing efforts in capacity building, content updation, etc.
2.  Targeted Financial Literacy Initiatives by:
 a) Using Differentiated content and focused delivery channels by involving entities connected with the target segments with functional linkages to boost the quality and effectiveness of financial literacy extension initiatives. The National Centre for Financial Education (NCFE) may conceptualise and execute an appropriate delivery model for targeted FL content to cater to the needs of students, elderly, migrants, different ly abled, and other similar groups on a sustained basis.
 b) Establishing financial literacy units at select schools, colleges, farmer -producer organizations (FPOs), community organisations, etc., to disseminate contextualised and focused FL content in addition to existing CFL mechanisms.
3.  Improving Digital Literacy by augmenting digital literacy to enable people to identify attempts to defraud, while allaying the concerns of people relating to safety and security of digital transactions; NCFE and financial service providers may run focussed and innovative campaigns.
4.  Development and dissemination of content on areas of emerging relevance. NCFE may develop suitable content on the following aspects for dissemination through Centers for Financial Literacy (CFLs), Financial Literacy Centers (FLCs), and other channels –
 a) Promoting sustainable indebtedness and guarding against over -indebtedness in households.
 b) Developing understanding about realistic financial goal setting, need for financial planning, and diversification of savings/investments.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the recommendations for periodic assessment of the state of financial literacy, developing AI & ML-based public query systems, and strengthening customer protection and grievance redressal measures?
output: NCFE may conduct periodic surveys to assess the state of financial literacy and financial inclusion, and based on the gaps assessed through the survey findings, NCFE may conceptualise and execute awareness initiatives for specific regions/ groups. Financial service providers should make available a duly authenticated public query systems for clarifying doubts and seeking information through their websites and social media extensions and conduct suitably positioned social media campaigns for effective dissemination of engaging content on consumer protection and grievance redressal measures. Easy, reliable, trusted, and effective customer protection and grievance redressal measures are needed, as the effectiveness of customer protection remains at the core of the demand for financial services.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What action points are recommended to improve the Grievance Redress Mechanism and reduce the high customer burden?
output:
To improve the Grievance Redress Mechanism and reduce the high customer burden, the following action points are recommended:

1. **Simpler Solutions:** Grievance redressal processes at Financial Service Providers (FSPs) should be made simpler to reduce the customer’s time and resources. This can include missed call service numbers for registering grievances, prompting a call back from the service provider with updates via SMS. Simple apps/solutions supporting complaint filing in regional languages should also be developed.

2. **Effective use of Citizen Financial Cyber Frauds Reporting and Management System (CFCFRMS):** Banks should use the CFCFRMS to address financial fraud complaints. This platform involves law enforcement agencies, banks, and FSPs working together. Banks should implement a mechanism for withholding/blocking funds related to complaints raised in CFCFRMS, accessible in near real-time. Complaints can be filed through helpline number 1930 or on the National Cybercrime Reporting Portal (NCRP).

3. **Board approved Customer Grievance Redress Policy:** Financial sector regulators should ensure all FSPs have a well-documented, Board-approved Customer Grievance Redress Policy. This policy should be widely publicized, prominently displayed on their websites, and provide a direct link to lodge complaints at all customer interface points/media.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What measures are being taken to strengthen customer protection in the financial sector?
output: Several measures are being implemented to strengthen customer protection. These include: (a) Establishing a Digital Payments Intelligence Platform to mitigate payment frauds by using advanced technologies and real-time data sharing across payment systems, expected to be operational by December 2026. (b) Providing protection against dark patterns by issuing guidelines to financial service providers, preventing them from manipulating or impeding customers' choices. (c) Implementing guardrails against tech innovations to address unintended customer protection issues such as data breaches, manipulations, frauds, and unfair practices. This involves regulators leveraging supervisory processes and taking strict supervisory action. (d) Ensuring the use of pre-intimated official phone numbers by banks to help customers distinguish between genuine communications from the bank and fraudulent impersonations.

Financial sector regulators may also prescribe regular awareness campaigns for customers on suitable themes by financial services providers.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the identified challenges or impediments to financial inclusion and the corresponding strategic objectives and action points?
output:
Identified challenges/impediments to financial inclusion, strategic objectives, action points, and implementing stakeholders include:

Gaps in operations of BC agents and inadequate monitoring are addressed by strengthening of BC Registry.
The need for further expansion and deepening of digital financial services is met by reaching one billion users in digital payments and Expanding and Deepening Digital Payment Ecosystem (EDDPE).
The need for targeted credit flow by leveraging digital channels is facilitated by Programmable CBDC to Facilitate Targeted Credit Flow and Expand Access and Unified Lending Interface (ULI) as a DPI.
The need for improving financial resilience at the household level is addressed by onboarding all banks and insurance companies to Jansuraksha Portal and increasing coverage of APY.
Low usage of financial services due to complex interfaces and language barriers is tackled by Simpler Digital Interfaces.
Credit gaps for micro enterprises are addressed by ensuring that micro enterprises receive focussed attention.
Encouraging adoption of code of conduct and best practices is done by Promoting Responsible Innovation through Self-Regulatory Organisations.
Insufficient representation of women as BC agents is addressed by adopting a Gender-Sensitive Approach for Women-led Financial Inclusion and Differentiated Strategies for Improving Financial Resilience of Households, especially for the Underserved and Vulnerable segments, including increasing the share of women business correspondents.
Lack of focused and suitable services to vulnerable/underserved segments is addressed by identifying vulnerable and underserved segments for focused services and by providing differentiated suitable products and delivery channels for underserved and vulnerable segments.
Ineffective financial resilience at the household level is improved by developing suitable bundled products in investment, pension, and insurance domain.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What monitoring and measurement mechanisms does the NSFI envision for achieving universal financial inclusion, and what indicators are typically classified under to assess progress?
output: The NSFI envisions an ecosystem approach towards achieving universal financial inclusion, with periodic evaluation and measurement integral to the strategy to gauge the impact of measures taken. Suitable indicators are identified to assess progress and the impact of policy formulations. Indicators related to financial inclusion are typically classified under ‘Access’, ‘Usage’ and ‘Quality’ with associated disaggregation to allow for detailed evaluation based on geography and demography (gender, age, income, etc.). Supply side assessment can be facilitated through regulatory returns and other readily available data points, while demand side assessment necessitates conduct of studies/surveys to gain insights into the quality of financial inclusion and identify enablers for advancing financial inclusion. It is recommended that the state of financial inclusion be measured and monitored to cover both the supply side (type of financial products and services, and delivery channels) and the demand side (factors that affect the usage of financial services).

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the key recommendations for data collection and demand-side measurement to improve financial inclusion assessment?
output:
To improve financial inclusion assessment, several key recommendations are made. First, data collection efforts should cover all formal financial institutions in the financial inclusion ecosystem. Second, data should be captured at the district level, disaggregated by gender and age, to facilitate assessment of geographical, gender, and age-related dimensions in access and usage of financial products and services and gain cross-sectional insights. Customer data captured by financial services providers should include broad categories such as income level, education, occupation, and purpose to enable analysis and better positioning of policy measures. Widely acceptable and harmonized data definitions should be developed for select terminologies, such as Vulnerable Consumers and Migrants, for use across the financial sector for suitable interventions. Additionally, there is a need for developing a disaggregated FI Index, preferably at the State/UT level, to assess the extent of financial inclusion at the regional level.
In conjunction with supply-side data collection, demand-side measurement is necessary to gather details about the barriers to access and usage of financial services, and quality of inclusion, especially at the last mile. This can be done through demand-side surveys/focus group studies, which can reveal the drivers of financial inclusion and help identify socio-economic factors, suitability of products and services, debt vulnerabilities at the household level, level of financial literacy and capability, and the state of grievance redress. Focusing on the end user’s perspective, the demand-side measurement has the potential to throw light on aspects such as alignment of need and demand, bottlenecks in the delivery of financial services at the last mile, regional inadequacies, and evolving preferences.

output: It is recommended that financial sector regulators establish a mechanism for conducting regular studies/surveys to assess the state of financial inclusion. Furthermore, the adoption of a holistic and synergistic approach to financial inclusion is seen as the way forward. This includes integrating financial inclusion policies with financial education, customer protection, skill development, livelihood support, entrepreneurship, and market linkages, using a multi-stakeholder approach. This integration can enable desired outcomes such as improved financial safety, financial security, financial resilience, and financial discipline, ultimately contributing towards the well-being of people.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What were the milestones and achievements of the NSFI (2019-24) Strategic Pillar – I: Universal Access to Financial Services?
output:
The milestones and achievements of the NSFI (2019-24) Strategic Pillar – I: Universal Access to Financial Services are as follows:

Milestones:
*   Increasing outreach of banking outlets of Scheduled Commercial Banks /Payments Banks/ Small Finance Banks, to provide banking access to every village within a 5 KM radius/ hamlet of 500 households in hilly areas by March 2020.
*   Strengthen eco-system for various modes of digital financial services in all the Tier-II to Tier VI centres to create the necessary infrastructure to move towards a less cash society by March 2022.
*   Leverage on the developments in fin -tech space to encourage financial service providers to adopt innovative approaches for strengthening outreach through virtual modes including mobile apps so that every adult has access to a financial service provider through a mobile device by March 2024.
*   Move towards an increasingly digital and consent-based architecture for customer onboarding by March 2024.

Achievements:
1.  As per the milestone,1.21 lakh villages were identified for providing banking access within a radius of 5 Kms/hamlet of 500 households. In this regard, more than 99.9 percent villages have been provided with some form of banking access.
2.  In order to facilitate digital on -boarding of customers by leveraging the latest technology, RBI amended the Master Direction on KYC dated February 25, 2016 on January 9, 2020 to introduce Video based Customer Identification Process (V-CIP) for customer on -boarding. This is an alternative, consent -based customer on -boarding process with certain risk -mitigants and can be implemented using digital devices such as mobile phones etc. In addition, ‘Digital KYC’ and ‘Equivalent e -Documents’, as provided in the am endment dated August 19, 2020 to the PML Rules, have also been introduced in the Master Direction on KYC for digital on-boarding of the customers.
3.  To further leverage V-CIP for customer due diligence (CDD), RBI vide changes in the MD on KYC dated May 10, 2021, has expanded the scope of Video based Customer Identification Procedure (V-CIP) to include all categories of customers including Authorised Si gnatories and Beneficial Owners of Legal Entities.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the key achievements and initiatives related to digital financial services and innovation in India?
output:
Key achievements and initiatives include: 

1. RBI amended the Master Direction on KYC to introduce Video based Customer Identification Process (V-CIP) for customer on-boarding, leveraging Aadhaar and the Centralised KYC Registry, with periodical up-dation enabled using V-CIP.

2. Regulatory Sandbox mechanism has been institutionalised, hosting five cohorts to test different products. A Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for Inter-operable Regulatory Sandbox (IoRS) has been put in place to facilitate innovation of financial products/service providers falling under multiple financial sector regulators.

3. RBI facilitated linking of credit cards with UPI, enabling small merchants with QR codes to participate in credit spends. UPI Lite, an on-device wallet, offers payment facility up to ₹ 1,000 without a UPI PIN, reducing the load on CBS and increasing transaction success rates. UPI Lite X (offline payments) was launched in September 2023, allowing UPI payments (P2P and P2M) of up to ₹500 without a mobile network.

4. A framework for Facilitating Small Value Digital Payments in Offline Mode was initiated by DPSS, RBI in January 2022.

5. Conversational payments were launched in September 2023, enabling users to engage with an AI-powered system for transactions in Indian regional languages, increasing payment accessibility and inclusion for senior citizens, divyangjan, and new users.

6. The Reserve Bank has set up the Reserve Bank Innovation Hub (RBIH) to promote innovation across the financial sector.

7. IRDAI has notified a Regulatory Sandbox, examining over 300 proposals and providing approvals for fintech deployment in onboarding, policy service, and claim settlement.

8. IRDAI has instructed stakeholders on the progressive implementation of digital-based customer on-boarding, policy servicing, and policyholder education.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are some initiatives taken by IRDAI and other financial institutions to enhance customer engagement and access to financial services?
output:
IRDAI and other institutions have launched several initiatives to improve customer engagement and access to financial services. These include:

1.  Insurers using customer portals, mobile apps, WhatsApp, and web-based tools to engage with customers. Approximately 60% of insurers have launched mobile apps for insurance sales and services, with IRDAI working to ensure all adults have access through mobile devices.
2.  Insurers now offering a range of policy terms, with a minimum of one month, for individual pure risk, group term, group credit life, and micro insurance products.
3.  Revised regulations for rural and social sector obligations for insurers. General insurance now focuses on the number of policies issued at the Gram Panchayat level, emphasizing coverage for motor vehicles, dwellings, and shops. Life and Health insurance now consider the number of lives covered under life, health, or personal accident insurance in a gram panchayat.
4.  Expanded scope of the social sector to cover cardholders (BPL, E-Shram, MNREGA, DBT beneficiaries, Jan Dhan account holders) and beneficiaries under various insurance schemes. The proportion of lives stipulated as a social sector obligation has increased from 0.5-5% to 10% of all lives covered for all Life, General, and Standalone Health insurers.
5.  Increased the maximum number of tie-ups for Corporate Agents (CA) and Insurance Marketing Firms (IMF) to facilitate wider access to insurance. A CA can now tie up with 9 insurers (previously 3), and an IMF can tie up with 6 insurers (previously 2) in each line of business (life, general, and health).
6.  PFRDA has enabled Points of Presence (PoPs) to onboard subscribers under the National Pension System (NPS) through double-factor authentication and video KYC, and has made strides in digital consent-based architecture using offline/online Aadhaar.
7.  PFRDA has developed mobile applications for services related to NPS, NPS-Lite, Swavalamaban Scheme, and Atal Pension Yojana (APY).

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the milestones and achievements related to financial inclusion, co-ordination, and monitoring at the grass-root level, as well as the use of technology and composite indices for measuring financial inclusion?
output:
Milestones include clearly articulating the responsibilities/expectations of each stakeholder at the grass-root level to ensure convergence of action between the Government/Regulators/financial service providers/Civil Society, etc., with SLBCs reviewing and implementing the vision, action plans, and milestones during the NSFI period (2019-24). Also, leveraging Geo-Spatial Information Technology, a robust monitoring framework can be developed for monitoring progress under financial inclusion, with special emphasis on Aspirational Districts, North Eastern Region, and Left-Wing Extremist affected Districts, with a monitoring framework and a GIS dashboard to be developed by March 2022.

Achievements include SLBC/UTLBCs, in co-ordination with RBI ROs, monitoring and reviewing progress made under access to livelihood and skill development and social security schemes (PMJJBY, PMSBY, APY). The Government of India has launched a Geographic Information System (GIS) based app, namely Jan-Dhan Darshak (JDD) App, developed by the National Informatics Centre (NIC). The App displays the availability of banking outlets within 5 km of all inhabited villages. Coverage of unbanked villages is regularly monitored based on the information updated by banks on the JDD App, with SLBCs playing a constructive role in identifying unbanked locations and ensuring banking presence in all such locations. Furthermore, regarding monitoring the progress under financial inclusion, RBI has constructed a composite Financial Inclusion (FI) Index, which holistically measures the extent of financial inclusion in the country. The FI Index is a comprehensive index having sub-indices for the three dimensions of financial inclusion (access, usage, and quality), comprising parameters from all the financial domain viz. banking, insurance, pension, investment as well postal. The FI-Index has been published every year since 2021, offering insights into the progress made and helping to identify gaps in the FI space, to be addressed by the concerned stakeholder. Review of progress made under the FI-Index is also a regular agenda item in the meetings of the Technical Group of Financial Inclusion and Financial Literacy (TGFIFL) under the Financial Stability and Development Council – Sub Committee (FSDC-SC).

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What role do Urban Cooperative Banks (UCBs) play in India, and what challenges do they face?
output:
The Primary (Urban) Cooperative Banks (UCBs) play an important role in furthering financial inclusion by generally providing traditional, if not the more modern, banking services to persons in the less included segments of the economic strata. World over, financial cooperatives in different forms, as banks and closed loop societies with access to the payment system, have varying market presence. In India, only the financial cooperatives which are licensed to undertake banking business are regulated and supervised by the financial sector regulator, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI). The banks in the rural cooperative sector are supervised by NABARD, although regulated by the RBI.
UCBs have the potential to be the harbinger of economic empowerment of the large number of financially excluded persons in the country. As per information provided to the Committee, the number of borrowers of UCBs is 67 lakh. This is not a small number by itself and there are many cases of transformational changes that UCBs have brought to its customers. However, seen in the context of a very large number of persons yet to have access to formal credit, what has been achieved is not enough either from the standpoint of potential or need. The factors that have resulted in sub-potential performance of the UCB sector are multifarious, some endogenous to the sector and others external.
There were two broad sources of constraints because of which the sector has underperformed. The first set of factors are internal to the sector. Many UCBs are small and do not have either the capability - financial or human resources – and/or possibly inclination to provide technology-enabled financial services. These banks continue to leverage on member loyalty to remain in business. This can wane with time, generational changes and, of course, competition. Secondly, because of their small size, a large number of these banks have not had the benefit of professional management and committed governance by people who understand not only the spirit of co-operation but also principles of banking to take a bank to the next level. While one of the arguments for the existence of smaller cooperatives is that they actually reduce intermediation costs, the empirical evidence of the relatively higher Net Interest Margins ( NIMs) of the smaller cooperative banks may be pointing to the contrary. These are not translating into sustainable return on assets either. While high cost to income ratio coupled with high NPAs are among the reasons, the unsustainability of the low scale of operations is at the core of the problem.
The second set of constraints are external to the banks. These emanate from the rather restrictive regulatory environment under which they have had to operate. This regulatory approach has been driven by several factors.
