(b) Sourcing of NPA – Centralised AMCs are set up when the NPAs arise due to systemic problems. Bank-specific AMCs are set up when NPA issues are limited to a few individual banks. An example of a bank-specific AMC framework is Sweden where Securum and Retrieva were established in 1992 to work out the NPAs of Nordbanken and Gota Bank, respectively.

(c) Voluntary vs mandatory transfer – In order to counter the reluctance of banks to recognize losses upfront while dealing with a systemic NPA problem, the option of mandatory transfer to AMC is used. In other scenarios, voluntary transfer is used, especially if not all banks are affected by NPA problems. Voluntary transfer allows for a level playing field across banks so that banks transferring bad assets to the AMC do not gain an unfair advantage over the others, by strengthening their balance sheets more than their peers.

(d) Valuing of NPA in the books of AMC – When AMCs are used for warehousing of the assets, an important consideration is how to account for the assets acquired. If these are valued at fair value, short-term mark-to-market price variations can adversely affect their value, defeating one of the objectives of putting these in AMCs. On the other hand, keeping the assets at book value can reduce the AMC’s incentive to dispose them off and, hence, unduly prolong the life of the asset.

Naturally, the varied design possibilities imply that the performance of an AMC/ARC like entity can be judged only against the objective for which it has been established. However, international experience suggests that the performance generally depends on the operational independence, adequacy of resources, technical competence and the type and quality of assets the se specialised institutions acquire. In this respect, the technical competence of these entities becomes extremely important. Typically, these specialised institutions acquire bad assets which the originators had failed to keep at performing levels. Therefore, the only way they would be able to extract value from such assets is if they have some comparative advantage over the originators in terms of management skills. In the absence of any comparative advantage over the lenders , AMC will only serve the limited purpose of cleaning up banks’ balance sheet s and will eventually becom e ineffective. In th is sense, it is imperative that these specialised institutions are differentially empowered though legal and regulatory frameworks.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How does the Committee plan to improve the performance and relevance of the ARC sector?
output: The Committee has attempted to reflect design principles related to ownership of AMCs, method of transfer of stressed assets, sourcing and valuation of stressed assets in its recommendations. It is expected that a principle-based redesigning of the ARC model would go a long way in improving the performance and relevance of the sector.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What is the legal framework governing Asset Reconstruction Companies (ARCs) in India, and what activities are they permitted to undertake according to the Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Security Interest (SARFAESI) Act?
output:
ARCs are registered and regulated under the Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Security Interest (SARFAESI) Act. They acquire financial assets from banks/ FIs either on their own books or in the books of a trust set up for the purpose of securitisation and/ or reconstruction. Section 10 of the Act outlines the other permissible activities of the ARCs. Accordingly, ARCs are permitted to undertake only the business of asset reconstruction, securitisation and other fee-based business as enumerated under Section 10(1) of the Act. Any other activity can be undertaken by these entities only with the prior approval of RBI. Some of the important provisions of the Act specifically pertaining to ARCs are enumerated below:
Section 3 Registration of ARCs
Section 4 Cancellation of Certificate of Registration
Section 5 Acquisition of Rights or Interest in Financial Assets
Section 7 Issue of Security by Raising of Receipts or Funds by ARCs
Section 8 Exemption from Registration of Security Receipt
Section 9  Measures for Asset Reconstruction
Section 10 Other Functions of ARC
Section 12 Power of RBI to determine Policy and issue Directions
Section 12A Power of RBI to call for Statements and Information
Section 12B Power of RBI to carry out Audit and Inspection
Section 30A  Power of Adjudicating Authority to impose Penalty
Section 30B Appeal against Penalties
Section 30C Appellate Authority. Section 2(1)(c) and Section 2(1)(m) of the Act define the terms ‘bank’ and ‘financial institution(FI)’, respectively. For the purpose of the Act, bank means a banking company as defined under Section 5(c) of the Banking Regulation Act, 1949 (B R Act), or a corresponding new bank as defined under Section 5(da) of B R Act, or the State Bank of India, or a multi -state co-operative bank. The Central Government has been empowered by the Act to notify any other class of banks for the purpose of this Act. FI under the Act includes public financial institution as defined in Companies Act, 2013, International Finance Corporation established under the International Finance Corporation (Status, Immunities and Privileges) Act, 1958, specified institutions under Section 2(h)(ii) of RDDBFI Act, a debenture trustee registered with

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the implications of an entity being classified as a Financial Institution (FI) under the Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Security Interest (SARFAESI) Act, and how do Asset Reconstruction Companies (ARCs) utilize trusts for securitization?
output:
According to Section 5(1) of the Act, ARCs can acquire financial assets from banks and FIs as defined under the Act. Another significance of an entity (e.g. a NBFC) being classified as FI under the Act is that it also gets enforcement powers with respect to secured financial assets under Section 13 besides the eligibility to sell financial assets to ARCs. Section 7 of the Act empowers ARCs to issue security receipts (SRs) and only qualified buyers (QBs) are permitted to acquire such SRs. Section 2(1)(u) of the Act defines QBs to include a financial institution, insurance company, bank, state financial corporation, state industrial development corporation, ARC or any asset management company making investment on behalf of mutual fund or a SEBI registered foreign institutional investor, any category of non -institutional investors as may be specified by RBI or any other body corporate as may be specified by SEBI.
ARCs for the purpose of securitisation create trusts which are governed by the provisions of the Indian Trust Act, 1882. Section 7(2A) of the SARFAESI Act specifies that such trusts are to be managed by ARCs, and ARCs shall hold the assets in trust for the benefit of the QBs . ARC regulations require that ARCs, as trustees, compulsorily invest and remain invested in at least 15% of the SRs of each class till the redemption of all the SRs issued by them under each scheme. ARCs skin in the game helps in aligning the interest of QBs (beneficiary) and the ARCs(trustee). Selling lenders may also acquire SRs as part of the consideration for transfer of assets to the trust. In fact, this has been the dominant practice till 2016. Typical transactions involved in securitisation done by ARCs are indicated in the Figure C1.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the requirements for ARCs regarding the realization of financial assets and what measures of asset reconstruction can they use?
output: On acquisition of financial assets, ARCs are required to realise the financial assets within the maximum permitted period of eight years from the date of acquisition. Section 9(1) of the SARFAESI Act prescribes measures of asset reconstruction that can be used by ARCs. The term ‘Asset Reconstruction’ is defined under Section 2(1)(b) of the Act as acquisition by any ARC of any right or interest of any bank or financial institution in any financial assistance for the purpose of realisation of such financial assistance. The Act empowers RBI under Section 9(2) to issue guidelines on the measures of asset reconstruction and Section 9(3) makes it binding on ARCs to take these measure in accordance with RBI guidelines.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the key regulations and guidelines pertaining to the functioning of Asset Reconstruction Companies (ARCs) as defined by the RBI and the SARFAESI Act?
output: RBI has issued guidelines in the "Securitisation Companies and Reconstruction Companies (Reserve Bank) Guidelines and Directions, 2003" covering registration, asset reconstruction measures, company functions, prudential norms, and financial asset acquisition. A list of important guidelines issued by RBI regarding the working of the ARCs is given in Annex II, consolidated as of July 2015 and needing updates. Key aspects include: Sponsor definition (holding at least 10% of ARC equity), fit and proper criteria for Sponsors (RBI Master Direction dated October 25, 2018), and prior RBI approval for appointments/re-appointments of directors/MD/CEO or changes in Sponsors. Other important regulations include: minimum Net Owned Fund (Rs.100 crore), restrictions on bilateral asset acquisition from sponsor banks/FIs or group entities, minimum 15% SRs investment in each class, asset realization timeline (5 years + 3 years with board approval), CRAR of 15%, and asset classification norms.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the regulatory provisions for asset classification, provisioning requirements, income recognition, and measures for asset reconstruction according to RBI guidelines?
output:
Regarding asset classification, assets held in the books of an ARC are classified as follows: Standard assets are those within a 6-month planning period or are not Non-Performing Assets (NPA); Sub-standard assets are those classified as NPA for no more than twelve months; Doubtful assets remain sub-standard for over twelve months; and Loss assets are non-performing for over 36 months, or financial assets including SRs are not realized within the specified time frame.

Provisioning requirements are as follows: Sub-standard assets require 10% provisioning of the outstanding amount. For Doubtful assets: (i) 100% provision is required to the extent the asset is not covered by the estimated realisable value of security; (ii) An additional 50% of the remaining outstanding amount is also required. For Loss assets: (i) the entire asset shall be written off; (ii) if the asset is retained in the books, 100% shall be provided for.

Income recognition guidelines state that yield on SRs and upside income should be recognized only after full redemption of SRs. Management fees should be calculated as a percentage of the net asset value (NAV) at the lower end of the range specified by the Credit Rating Agency.

The Act empowers the RBI under Section 9(2) to issue guidelines on measures for reconstruction of assets. A brief snapshot of these guidelines is as follows:
Change in/ Takeover of Management of the Business of the Borrower
▪ In accordance with provisions of Section 15 of the Act and as per Board approved policy;
▪ If amount due to the ARC trust is at least 25% of the total assets owned by the borrower . If borrower is financed by more than one secured creditor (including ARC) holding not less than 60% of outstanding SRs agree to such action.
▪ Grounds - Wilful default, incompetent management or the management acting against the interest of creditors, fraudulent transactions, etc.
Sale/ Lease of Business of the Borrower
 RBI has not issued necessary guidelines in this regard

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the important regulations regarding measures for asset reconstruction including rescheduling of debts, enforcement of security interest, settlement of dues and conversion of debt into equity?
output:
Measures Regulatory provisions:
Rescheduling of Debts payable by the Borrower: As per Board approved policy of the ARC.
Enforcement of Security Interest: In accordance with provisions of Section 13 of the Act. The ARC may acquire the secured assets, either for its own use or for resale, only if the sale is conducted through a public auction.
Settlement of Dues payable by the Borrower: As per Board approved policy.
Conversion of Debt into Equity in a Borrower Company: Shareholding by the ARC/ trust shall not exceed 26% or sectoral FDI limit of the post converted equity of the company under reconstruction. The 26% limit can be exceeded provided the ARC meets certain criteria. As per Board approved policy.
ARCs are permitted to deploy their funds for undertaking restructuring of acquired assets with the sole purpose of realising their dues. Trusts may also utilize a part of funds raised under a scheme from the QBs for restructuring of assets acquired under relative schemes subject to certain conditions. One of the conditions requires that the extent of funds that shall be utilized for reconstruction purpose should not be more than 25% of the funds raised under the scheme.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How do ARCs manage the recovery from asset resolution and what determines the management fee?
output: ARCs' efforts towards resolution of assets results in redemption of SRs. From the recovery made by ARCs, they claim the management fee for managing the assets, expenses and incentives, if any, from the respective trusts. Residual recovery is used to redeem the SRs issued to the QBs. Residual recovery in excess of the acquisition cost, generally referred to as ‘upside income’, is distributed among the QBs and ARCs as per the agreed terms. Management fee of ARCs is based on the NAV of the SRs. NAV in turn depends on the rating obtained from a SEBI registered Credit Rating Agency (CRA). ARCs are required to obtain the initial rating within a period of six months of acquisition of assets. Thereafter, the rating is reviewed by a CRA on half yearly basis. Rating is given in terms of 'recovery rating scale' which has an associated range of probable recovery expressed in percentage terms. NAV is arrived at by multiplying the face value of outstanding SRs with the lower end of the said range. Management fee is to be recognised on accrual basis and is to be reversed, if not realised within 180 days.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the regulations regarding the NAV of Security Receipts (SRs) for Asset Reconstruction Companies (ARCs) and the actions Qualified Buyers (QBs) can take if assets are not realized within a specific timeframe?
output: Extant guidelines for ARCs provide that the rationale for the rating should be disclosed by CRAs to ARCs on an ongoing basis and if NAV falls below 50% of face value within a certain period, it triggers certain actions. Prudential accounting norms require that SRs held by the ARC which have not been redeemed within the maximum permitted timeframe of 8 years are to be treated as loss assets. Under Section 7(3) of the Act, in the event of non-realisation of assets within the specified timeframe, QBs holding SRs of not less than seventy-five percent of the total value of SRs issued under a scheme are empowered to call a meeting of all the QBs and pass a resolution binding on the ARC.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What does the business of ARCs involve, and what trends have been observed in asset acquisition by ARCs?
output: The business of ARCs involves acquisition of stressed assets from lenders and recovery using various measures of asset reconstruction, and it typically also involves securitisation of acquired assets. Acquisition of assets by ARCs, in terms of book value, grew at a CAGR of 27.2% for the period FY04 to FY21. A considerable jump in acquisition was seen in FY14, followed by an overall upward trend over the succeeding years. Data shows that overall 79.8% of assets flowing into the ARC sector has been from the banks. Assets acquired from PSBs alone constituted 51.6% of the total assets acquired by the ARC sector. However, FY17 onwards, ARCs have been acquiring financial assets from a diverse set of entities. NBFCs have emerged as a significant class of sellers of stressed assets since the notification of select NBFCs as FIs for the purpose of Act in FY17. During the period FY17-FY21 acquisition from NBFCs grew at a CAGR of 87.9%. In fact, in FY21, NBFCs were the largest supplier of stressed assets among the eligible entities. The emergence of NBFCs as a significant class of sellers can be attributed to multiple factors, including the Central Government notifying an increasing number of NBFCs as FIs (currently, all NBFCs with an asset size of Rs.100 crore and above are notified as FIs) and the liquidity crunch faced by the NBFC sector around FY19.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What factors contributed to the increased role of NBFCs in supplying financial assets to ARCs and the shrinking of banks' sales of financial assets to ARCs?
output: The increase in NBFCs’ share in the supply of financial assets to ARCs can be partly attributed to the shrinking of banks’ sale of financial assets to ARCs. Public Sector Banks' (PSBs) sales to ARCs have been declining from FY19 onwards. One factor behind this decline may be the introduction of progressive provisioning for banks’ Security Receipt (SR) based deals, which was introduced via RBI circular dated September 1, 2016, and came into full force from FY19 onwards. A comparison between the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA, including assets sold to ARC) of scheduled commercial banks and ARC’s acquisition of financial assets from banks for the period of FY08 to FY19 indicates that post-FY14, there has been a downward trend in the percentage of NPAs sold to ARCs despite the upward trend in the level of GNPA in SCBs. Apart from progressive provisioning, the emergence of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC) as an alternative resolution mechanism may have also contributed to this trend.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What factors might explain the decline in the average discount rate for financial assets acquired by ARCs between FY14-FY21 compared to the period before it?
output: The decline in the discount rate, from an average of 66% during FY04 -FY21, may reflect increased quality consciousness of ARCs, as the 'skin in the game' requirement for them (to hold in the ARC’s own books a minimum percentage of the SRs issued) was increased to 15% from 5% vide circular dated August 05, 2014.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What was the redemption rate of Security Receipts (SRs) issued by the ARC sector during FY04-FY13, and what does this imply regarding the recovery of amounts owed by borrowers?
output: From FY04 to FY13, Security Receipts (SRs) issued by the ARC sector accounted for 68.6% of the total value of SRs issued. However, the redemption of SRs issued during this period, as a percentage of the book value of stressed assets acquired, was only 14.29%. This means that banks and other investors could recover only about 14% of the amount owed by their borrowers. This data, combined with the fact that a significant portion of SRs have had to be written off, indicates two issues with the current market: low rates of redemption and inflated acquisition costs. The discount rate on book value has been high. It also suggests the importance of creating incentives to ensure that the price discovery process yields the true value of SRs, minimizing write-offs and aligning the discount to asset book value with the realisable value of the assets sold.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What factors deter lenders from selling stressed assets to ARCs, and what incentives can be offered to encourage such sales, particularly for assets with low vintage?
output: One of the significant deterrents to the sale of stressed assets by lenders to ARCs is that they are required to book the losses on an immediate basis. This especially acts as a deterrent for the sale of recent (low vintage) NPAs with lower levels of provisioning on the lenders’ books. On the other hand, when lower vintage NPAs are assigned to ARCs, the chances of revival/maximization of recovery are higher. ARCs may be able to resolve such NPAs through revival of business before resorting to other legal options for recovery. In order to incentivize lenders to sell stressed assets, especially with a focus on those assets with low vintage, certain options may be considered, including extending the dispensation to allow banks to spread the loss on the sale of financial assets to ARCs over a period of two years, subject to suitable disclosures in the published accounts. Currently, on the sale of an asset below Net Book Value, lenders are required to provide for the shortfall at the time of sale. However, as per guidelines dated February 26, 2014, as an incentive for the early sale of NPAs, RBI had given a dispensation to banks for amortizing the shortfall on the sale of NPAs to ARCs, over a period of two years. The dispensation was valid up to March 31, 2015, but was later extended till March 31, 2016 vide circular dated May 21, 2015. Subsequently vide circular dated June 13, 2016, for assets sold between April 1, 2016 to March 31, 2017, banks were allowed to amortize the shortfall over a period of four quarters.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the guidelines regarding provisioning for losses at the time of sale and investments in Security Receipts (SRs) by banks, and what are the recommendations for promoting realistic price discovery?
output:
Gross Exposure (A) Rs.100 
Provisioning (B) Rs.15 
Net Exposure (C=A-B) Rs.85 
Sale Consideration (D)  Rs.50 
Loss at the time of Sale (E=C-D) Rs.35 
Provisioning required in terms of current guidelines is Rs.35 on sale. Recommended guidelines for provisioning are: Year 1 @50% of Loss : Rs.17.50, Year 2 @50% of Loss : Rs.17.50. With effect from April 1, 2018, where the investment by a bank is more than 10% of SRs backed by assets sold by itself, the provisions held in respect of these SRs will be subject to a floor; this floor shall be progressive provisioning as per extant asset classification and provisioning norms. Provisioning requirement in such cases will be the higher of the provisioning rate required in terms of NAV declared by the ARC and provisioning rate as applicable to the underlying loans, assuming that the loans notionally continued in the books of the bank. These provisioning requirements aim to promote investments in SRs by the non-originator entities, thereby ensuring a more realistic price discovery. In cases where majority investment in SRs (say 51% or more) is through external parties (ARC and investors, other than lenders), the economic model presented in Annex III suggests that market transactions would have ensured a realistic price discovery. For such transactions, the Committee recommends that provisioning on residual SRs held by the selling banks may be made on the basis of NAV declared by the CRA and not as per IRACP norms. This would incentivize banks to sell financial assets to ARCs. The threshold of 51% is sensitive to the cost of capital of the investors, the rate of management fees, and the value created by the ARC through its reconstruction activities. As the market matures, we expect the risk of holding SRs to fall, thus reducing the cost of capital. Consequently, the levels of management fees are likely to drop. Both developments would increase the threshold of investment by external parties that would ensure discovery of true value. In parallel, more effective reconstruction activities would decrease the threshold. Hence, the Committee recommends that the 51% threshold may be applicable for two years and increased to 76% after due consideration of the various factors involved.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the recommendations regarding the sale of NPAs to ARCs and provisioning on SRs held by lenders, as well as the sale of SMA accounts to ARCs?
output: RBI may provide a dispensation to lenders on an ongoing basis for amortising the loss on sale of NPAs to ARCs, over a period of two years. When substantial investment in SRs (say 51% or more) is by investors other than the lenders, provisioning on SRs held by the lenders may be done based on net asset value declared by the ARC. The threshold of 51% may be applicable for two years and increased to 76% thereafter. Lenders may be permitted to sell accounts reported as SMAs to ARCs to enable early assignment of debt and better reconstruction of stressed assets. This will also facilitate more efficient debt aggregation where the exposure to the same borrower is classified differently by different lenders, depending on the record of recovery. It is likely that SMA-0 and SMA-1 assets sold to ARCs could be reconstructed mainly through revival of the business whereas reconstruction of SMA-2 assets may also involve enforcement of security if the account is subsequently classified as NPA. At the same time, SMA borrowers need to be protected from precipitate enforcement of security interest by ARCs which may arbitrarily classify them as NPAs for enforcing security.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the recommendations of the committee regarding the sale/auction of NPAs and policies for resolution of stressed assets?
output:
The Committee notes that at the beginning of the year, banks are required to make a list of such NPAs which they intend to sell/ auction to other banks/ NBFCs/ ARCs/ other eligible entities. The Committee recommends that such a list should be prepared by all regulated lenders and disclosed to all ARCs after entering into a confidentiality agreement, with an information memorandum of such assets kept ready and updated on a continuing basis. 
Under RBI’s Prudential Framework for Resolution of Stressed Assets, lenders are required to have Board approved policies for resolution of stressed assets, which need to include a policy on sale of stressed assets to ARCs, indicating the circumstances and parameters that will be considered for such a sale. 
For accounts of Rs.100 crore and above, which are in default, the committee recommends: (a) Bank’s resolution plan should explicitly evaluate sale/ auction of NPAs to ARCs as one of the options; (b) In case of NPAs which are (i) more than two years old and (ii) no active resolution plan is in place and are not included in the list of NPAs identified for sale, the reason for their exclusion should be documented.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the recommendations regarding the sale of stressed assets to ARCs?
output:
The recommendations are as follows:
(a) It may be clarified that all categories of Special Mention Accounts can be considered for sale to ARCs. To protect the interest of borrowers, suitable safeguards may be provided through regulatory prescription on enforcement of security interest.
(b) At the beginning of the year, all regulated lenders, and not just banks, should make a list of such NPAs which they intend to sell/ auction to eligible entities, including ARCs. The list should be disclosed to all ARCs on entering into a confidentiality agreement. Data / information on such assets should be kept ready and updated on an on-going basis (live updated memorandum).
(c) Lenders’ Board approved policies for resolution of stressed assets must include a policy on sale of stressed assets to ARCs, indicating the circumstances and parameters that will be considered for such a sale.
(d) For accounts in default with a lender for amount of Rs.100 crore and above,
(i) lender’s resolution plan should explicitly evaluate sale/ auction of NPAs to ARCs as one of the options;
(ii) In case of NPAs which are more than two years old and no active resolution plan is in place and if such accounts are not included in the list as at (b) above, the reason for their exclusion should be documented.
(e) Sale of fraud accounts to ARCs may be permitted subject to appropriate safeguards to ensure that fixing of accountability at lender level and criminal inquiry by competent authorities are not affected by this transfer.
(f) In the interest of debt aggregation, ARCs may be allowed to also acquire stressed loans to domestic borrowers from regulated overseas banks and financial institutions.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the recommendations for streamlining and standardizing the process of sale of stressed assets undertaken by banks/FIs?
output: The recommendations for streamlining and standardizing the process of sale of stressed assets undertaken by banks/FIs are as follows: The Secondary Loan Market Association (SLMA) may be asked to provide lenders with a suitable comprehensive checklist on necessary information to be given for due diligence to ARCs, and the data room should be open for a minimum of 30 days. There is a need for streamlining and standardising the process of sale of stressed assets undertaken by the banks/ FIs, as certainty and transparency in such processes are critical for the development of an efficient stressed assets market. The endeavour should be to make the auction process transparent and robust. Industry associations, such as the IBA, may provide a process document to selling banks/ FIs for ensuring certainty and transparency of auctions conducted by them. The auction mechanism should involve multidimensional bidding whereby winners should be decided based on qualitative and quantitative parameters, such as total deal value, cash proportion being offered, quality of management, and technical competence of ARCs. Lenders should be in a position to convert these (qualitative) parameters into cash equivalents for deciding the winning bid. For the purpose of ensuring transparency and uniformity of processes in the sale of stressed assets, a separate online platform may be created, utilizing infrastructure created by SLMA. Banks should determine the reserve price in a realistic manner, and commercial considerations should take precedence in such determination. The reserve price set by a bank should reflect the value it could realize through its own restructuring capabilities (including resolution of the borrower through IBC), without trying to second guess what the ARC could realize given its capabilities in asset.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the committee's recommendations regarding the bidding process for financial assets and the roles of external valuers and high-level committees?
output: The Committee recommends that in bidding process followed by a lender, for all financial assets of Rs.500 crore and above of the lender, two lender-approved external valuers should carry out the determination of liquidation value and fair market value. For financial assets between Rs.100 crore to Rs.500 crore, one valuer may be engaged. The determination of the reserve price should be influenced by the output of the external valuations. Further, the final approval of the reserve price should be given by a high-level committee that has the power to write off the loan. Via a regulation, SLMA may provide lenders with a suitable comprehensive checklist on necessary information to be given to ARCs at pre -deal stage for due diligence and deal evaluation. Further, data room should be open for a minimum of 30 days after all information is furnished. Via a regulation, the IBA may provide a model process document to lenders for ensuring certainty and transparency of auctions conducted by them. Also, for the purpose of ensuring transparency and uniformity of processes in sale of stressed assets, a separate online platform may be established. Infrastructure created by SLMA may be utilised for this purpose. In the bidding process followed by banks/ FIs, for all financial assets of Rs.500 crore and above, two bank-approved external valuers should carry out the valuation exercise of liquidation value and fair market value. For financial assets between Rs.100 crore to Rs.500 crore, one valuer may be engaged. The determination of the Reserve Price should be influenced by the external valuations. Further, the final approval of the Reserve Price should be given by a high-level committee that has the power to write off the loan.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What entities should be allowed to sell financial assets to ARCs, and why is this broader scope beneficial?
output: The scope of Section 5 of the Act, and other related provisions, should be expanded to allow ARCs to acquire ‘financial assets’ as defined in the Act, for the purpose of reconstruction, not only from banks and ‘financial institutions’ but also from such entities as may be notified by the Reserve Bank. Today, AIFs, Mutual Funds, FPIs, etc., are actively providing funds to non-financial firms through subscription to debt securities, and retail investors are also investing in debt securities, including unsecured debt. Allowing ARCs to purchase financial assets from a broader range of entities would give impetus to debt aggregation, which is a necessity for the efficient resolution of stressed assets. Given that debt markets are continuously evolving, it seems fit to have a statutory provision that gives the Reserve Bank flexibility to specify, through regulations, entities from which ARCs can acquire financial assets, in addition to the banks and ‘financial institutions’ permitted under the Act. Under these proposed powers, the Reserve Bank may consider permitting ARCs to acquire financial assets from all regulated entities and also retail investors.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the Reserve Bank's considerations for permitting ARCs to acquire financial assets, and what scenarios allow ARCs to acquire debt from other ARCs without redeeming SRs?
output: The Reserve Bank may consider permitting ARCs to acquire financial assets from all regulated entities, including AIFs, FPIs, AMCs making investments on behalf of MFs, all NBFCs (including HFCs) irrespective of asset size, and from retail investors. ARCs can also acquire debt from other ARCs under extant regulations, subject to some conditions, including the utilization of sale proceeds for redemption of underlying SRs. However, aggregation of debt by an ARC from other ARCs need not always result in redemption of SRs. For example, multiple ARCs may have acquired portions of distressed debt pertaining to a single borrower, leading to multiple trusts managed by multiple ARC trustees, holding portions of the debt for the benefit of multiple and distinct classes of SR investors. In this case, it may be advantageous to bring these fragmented portions of the debt of the common borrower under the management of a common trustee ARC, where only the trusteeship and management of the trust assets would change hands from one ARC to another, with any purchase consideration for this transfer necessarily being in cash. Such transactions between ARCs should require approval by a specified majority, by value, of the SR investors concerned or such other prescribed threshold as may be defined by the subscription agreement/trust deed. In these scenarios, the selling ARC should not be required to redeem the associated SRs, and the acquiring ARC should be required to have 'skin in the game' by investing in the associated SRs to the extent of the prescribed minimum threshold. Permitting the existing SR holders to continue holding their SRs may give them the benefit of an upside, the likelihood of which increases with debt consolidation. The regulations should permit a change in the SR trustee/asset management role from one ARC to another, without necessarily extinguishing the SRs.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What is required for an ARC to acquire the management or trusteeship of a financial asset from another ARC, and what SR purchase obligations arise when SRs are not extinguished?
output: Any acquisition of management or trusteeship of a financial asset by an ARC from another ARC must have the approval of a majority, by value, of the SR holders concerned or such other prescribed threshold as may be defined by the subscription agreement or trust deed. If the SRs are not extinguished, any ARC acquiring trusteeship or management from another ARC will be required to purchase the associated SRs to the extent of the prescribed minimum threshold.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: According to section 9(1) of the SARFAESI Act, what measures for asset reconstruction can ARCs deploy, and what trends have been observed in their utilization of these measures?
output: According to section 9(1) of the SARFAESI Act, ARCs can deploy measures of asset reconstruction under the guidelines issued by RBI. Data indicates that approximately 80% of the recovery for the sector has come through methods that do not necessarily lead to business revival. ARCs have rarely used change or takeover of the management of business of the borrowers or conversion of borrowers’ debt into equity as measures for reconstruction. Rescheduling of payment of debts was also involved in only 19.9% of the recovery made by ARCs. This trend has been consistent over the life of the sector. The only change in this trend is use of IBC as a resolution mechanism after it became available. ARCs get the power to use IBC through IBC, 2016 and not through the Act. Assets bought after FY14 are increasingly being resolved through IBC. However, use of IBC by ARCs may not be indicative of a preference for IBC since ARCs’ participation in IBC may be involuntary, with the initiative being taken by primary lenders.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What factors determine the methods of asset reconstruction that Asset Reconstruction Companies (ARCs) can gainfully deploy, and what limitations do ARCs face in funding borrowers?
output: ARCs' ability to fund the borrower, regulatory limitations, and their skill sets determine the methods of asset reconstruction that ARCs can gainfully deploy. Limitations of the restructuring options usually force the ARCs either to take up the measures of recovery only or focus on such assets which do not require major resolution. In general, turnaround of stressed borrowers requires additional funding, requiring different sources of funding and various debt and equity instruments, including but not limited to share capital, priority debt, mezzanine debt, senior debentures, etc., to continue to run the operations efficiently. For a stressed borrower, raising such funds becomes difficult. Almost all stressed borrowers require additional working capital facilities, which are not available from the regular banking system due to adverse asset classification of such accounts. Therefore, for turning around companies, ARCs should be able to timely and sufficiently fund them. Today, there are many limitations for ARCs for funding such requirements. They are not able to provide interim finance in insolvency resolution processes or significantly contribute to a turnaround due to their inability to provide meaningful last mile funding. For undertaking any restructuring of such debt acquired by them, ARCs also have additional restrictions, which limit the extent of restructuring support finance which they can provide. Currently, this is capped at 25% of the funds raised by them under the scheme and should be disclosed upfront in the scheme.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the benefits of allowing ARCs to sponsor an AIF and how does it address the limitations of traditional financing sources for stressed asset resolution?
output:
Allowing ARCs to sponsor a SEBI registered AIF offers several benefits for reconstructing debt and turning around borrowers, including HNIs.  It provides increased flexibility in restructuring options, as investments into debt or equity can be funded directly from the AIF. Using the AIF as a source helps ARCs raise funds in a risk-mitigated manner based on their performance track record, aiding in turning around many stuck cases. The objective is to use the AIF as an additional vehicle to advance the purpose of the ARCs to facilitate restructuring/ recovery of the acquired debt. For revival of stressed companies, the ARCs may need flexibility to arrange the financial assistance from banks and FIs and additional capital for revival.

Given the limitation of traditional sources of financing for ARCs, the Committee recommends that, going forward, ARCs should be allowed to sponsor an AIF, duly registered with SEBI with the objective of investing in stressed assets could address the above constraints and provide an additional investor base. Allowing an ARC to sponsor a SEBI registered AIF is proposed as a way forward, to be used as an additional vehicle for facilitating restructuring / recovery of the debt acquired by the ARC and a meaningful turnaround of the borrower. The enabling power under Section 10(2) of the Act may be utilised for this purpose.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the committee's recommendations to improve debt aggregation and resolution of stressed assets by ARCs?
output: The committee recommends several measures to improve debt aggregation and the resolution of stressed assets. First, it suggests reducing the threshold for lenders' agreement on an ARC offer from 75% to 66%, aligning with the IBC majority voting threshold. A 60-day timeline for remaining lenders to comply with the majority decision should also be prescribed, with a mandate for 100% provisioning on the loan if a lender fails to comply. The committee also recommends that the planning period for formulating a resolution plan be extended from six months to one year to allow for preconditions for effective planning to be satisfied. For individual ARC exposures above a threshold of Rs.500 crore, a resolution plan that involves any restructuring of debt must satisfy a viability assessment analogous to that prescribed under the Prudential Framework for Resolution of Stressed Assets, i.e. an independent credit evaluation (ICE) by an authorised CRA with a credit opinion of RP4 or better for the residual debt. Furthermore, in cases where an ARC has acquired 66% of aggregate debt pertaining to a borrower, the Act should provide for a two-year moratorium on proceedings against the borrower by other authorities, and Government dues will be deferred in such cases.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the recommendations regarding the role and function of ARCs (Asset Reconstruction Companies) in stressed asset resolution, as outlined in the report?
output:
The recommendations regarding the role and function of ARCs (Asset Reconstruction Companies) in stressed asset resolution are as follows:
(a) If 66% of lenders (by value) decide to accept an offer by an ARC, the same may be binding on all lenders and must be implemented within 60 days of approval by majority lenders (66%). 100% provisioning on the loan outstanding should be mandated for a dissenting lender who fails to comply with this requirement.
(b) Planning period may be elongated to one year from the existing six months to allow for preconditions for effective planning to set in.
(c) For individual ARC exposures above a threshold, say, Rs.500 crore, a resolution plan that involves any restructuring of debt must satisfy a viability assessment along the lines prescribed under RBI’s Prudential Framework for Resolution of Stressed Assets, i.e. an independent credit evaluation (ICE) by an authorised CRA with a credit opinion of RP4 or better for the residual debt.
(d) In cases where ARCs have acquired 66% of debt of a borrower, the Act should provide for two years of moratorium on proceedings against the borrower by other authorities. The Act should also provide that Government dues including revenues, taxes, cesses and rates due to the Central Government, State Government or local authority will be deferred in such cases.
For better value realization for selling lenders and enhancing the effectiveness of ARCs in asset reconstruction, both debt and equity pertaining to a borrower may be allowed to be sold by lenders to ARCs with suitable checks and balances.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How can ARCs (Asset Reconstruction Companies) enhance their role in resolving stressed assets under the IBC (Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code) framework, and what conditions should be applied?
output: ARCs, while allowed to resolve financial assets through the IBC process as secured creditors, are not currently permitted to act as Resolution Applicants (RA) under IBC because their legal and regulatory design is focused on debt recovery rather than insolvency resolution. To enhance ARCs' ability to resolve stressed assets, they may be allowed to participate in IBC as a Resolution Applicant either through their SR trust or through the AIF sponsored by them. To ensure they focus on financial asset reconstruction, a principal business requirement (PBR) should be applicable, stating that the AUM (Assets Under Management) by the ARC acquired through AIF and IBC should not together exceed the AUM acquired via SR issuance at any time.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What recommendations are made regarding Section 9(1)(b) and Section 13 of the Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Security Interest Act, 2002 concerning Asset Reconstruction Companies (ARCs)?
output:
Section 9(1)(b) of the Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Security Interest (SARFAESI) Act, 2002 allows for the sale or lease of part or the whole of the borrower's business as a measure for asset reconstruction. However, RBI guidelines indicate that no ARC shall take this measure, until the RBI issues necessary guidelines in this behalf, which has not yet occurred. It is recommended that suitable guidelines to operationalize Section 9(1)(b) of the Act be issued by RBI.

Section 13 of the Act allows secured creditors to enforce security interest only in respect of assets classified by them as Non-Performing Assets (NPAs). While RBI has issued guidelines on asset classification of stressed assets on the ARCs’ own balance sheets, it has not issued any such guidelines on asset (specifically NPA) classification of assets held in trust structures managed by the ARC, such as the SR trusts or any other structure managed by the ARC. It is recommended that RBI consider issuing guidelines under Section 2(1)(o)(b) of the Act for ‘standard’ / NPA classification of assets managed by ARCs but not on their balance sheets. Since the classification is required only for the purpose of enforcement of security interest, it would suffice to distinguish between ‘standard’ assets and NPAs, without requiring sub-classification of NPAs or provisioning.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: Why is a vibrant secondary market for Security Receipts (SRs) essential, and what factors have hindered its development?
output:
A vibrant secondary market for SRs is essential for several reasons:

*   It is a prerequisite for providing an easy exit to Qualified Buyers (QBs) and to thereby attract more investors.
*   Increased investor participation may also facilitate better price discovery in the stressed assets market.
*   All this may, in turn, motivate lenders to sell stressed assets at an earlier stage and ARCs to attempt faster resolution.

SEBI has issued listing guidelines for the SRs vide Securities and Exchange Board of India (Public Offer and Listing of Securitised Debt Instruments) (Amendment) Regulations, 2018 dated June 26, 2018. However, despite the availability of the listing framework, listing and consequent trading of SRs through the exchanges has not taken off. For all practical purposes, there is no secondary market for SRs.

Data shows that the majority of the outstanding SRs are either being held by selling lenders as sale consideration or by the ARCs themselves due to regulatory requirement. Overall 65.7% of total SRs were held by selling lenders, followed by 19.9% by ARCs and only 14.4% of total SRs were held by other QBs.
One of the reasons behind lack of trading in SRs is the nature of the SR itself. There is no definitive obligation on the part of ARCs as trustees to redeem the SRs issued. ARCs are only obligated to distribute whatever is recovered from the underlying debt. However, SRs do provide a possibility of high return through upside if ARCs can make recovery above the nominal value of SRs issued.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What factors contribute to the limited uptake of Security Receipts (SRs) and what recommendations have been made to improve the secondary market for SRs?
output:
The limited uptake of Security Receipts (SRs) is due to factors such as the low upside provided by Asset Reconstruction Companies (ARCs) and the lack of a definitive obligation to redeem the SRs. The overall upside achieved by ARCs stood at 4.44% of the total SRs issued for the period FY04-FY21, and even the redemption of SRs has not been very encouraging. To strengthen the ARCs’ ability to resolve the underlying stressed assets and facilitate greater redemption and upside, various measures have been recommended, including realistic price discovery. It is expected that these recommendations will allow ARCs to generate attractive returns for SR investors and thereby help bring vibrancy in the secondary market for SRs.

Data shows a significant change in trend. During the period FY04-FY13 upside income was equally distributed among ARCs and other Qualifying Buyers (QBs). However, during FY14-FY21 overall 73.4% of upside seems to have gone to other QBs. This change can be explained by increased participation by varied classes of QBs. The Committee believes that broad basing the QBs may act as a catalyst for stimulating the secondary market for SRs. Therefore, to increase the investor base of SRs, the Committee recommends that the list of eligible QBs may be further expanded to include High Net Worth Individuals (HNIs) with minimum investment of Rs.1 crore, corporates (net worth-Rs.10 crore & above), Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs) even if not notified as Financial Institutions (FIs), trusts, family offices, pension funds, distressed asset funds with the condition that defaulting promoters should not be gaining access to secured assets through SRs.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What recommendations were made to broaden the investor base of Security Receipts (SRs) and address regulatory limitations on Asset Reconstruction Companies (ARCs)?
output: To broaden the investor base of SRs, the recommendation includes expanding the list of eligible qualified buyers to include HNIs with a minimum investment of Rs. 1 crore, corporates (Net Worth of Rs. 10 crore & above), NBFCs/HFCs not notified as FIs, trusts, family offices, pension funds, and distressed asset funds, with the conditions that defaulting promoters should not gain access to secured assets through SRs, and corporates cannot invest in SRs issued by ARCs which are related parties as per SEBI definition. Additionally, to leverage the existing capital of ARCs and enable more investor participation, the Committee recommends amendments to current regulations, including reducing the minimum contribution by an ARC to 2.5% of total SRs issued in each class and scheme for transactions on a 100% cash basis and reducing the minimum contribution to 15% of the SRs subscribed by lenders (subject to a minimum of 2.5% of total SRs issued, in each class/scheme) for transactions where lenders subscribe to SRs.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: Can you provide illustrative examples of the recommended ARC investment in SRs, contrasting the existing guidelines with the new recommendations, considering scenarios with and without selling bank/FI investment?
output:
Illustrative examples:

Example 1: Total value of SRs issued is Rs.100, and the investment in SRs by the selling bank/FI is Rs.40.
*   Existing Guidelines: ARC’s investment in SRs is Rs.15 (15% of purchase consideration).
*   Recommendation: 
    *   Memo: 15% of Investment in SRs by selling bank/ FI = 15% of Rs.40 = Rs.6.
    *   Memo: 2.5 % of total value of SRs issued = 2.5% of Rs.100 = Rs.2.50.
    *   ARC’s investment in SRs = Rs.6 (higher of Rs.6 and Rs.2.50).
    *   Therefore, investment in SRs by investor = Rs.54.

Example 2: Total value of SRs issued is Rs.100, and the investment in SRs by the selling bank/ FI is Rs.0.
*   Existing Guidelines: ARC’s investment in SRs is Rs.15 (15% of sale consideration).
*   Recommendation:
    *   Memo: 15% of Investment in SRs by selling bank/ FI = 15% of Rs.00 = Rs.0
    *   Memo: 2.5 % of total value of SRs issued = 2.5% of Rs.100 = Rs.2.50.
    *   ARC’s investment in SRs = Rs.2.50 (higher of Rs.0 and Rs.2.50).
    *   Therefore, investment in SRs by investor = Rs.97.50.

Apart from their minimum required investment in SRs, ARCs should be free to divest the remaining investment in SRs to QBs. Further, if an ARC ceases to be a manager/ trustee of an ARC scheme (e.g. as envisaged in para. D.1.16. ibid), it should be permitted to divest its entire investment in SRs of that scheme if it so desires. However, the extant regulations (para 5, proviso (iii) of the SC/RC Guidelines/Directions, 2003) stipulate that an ARC shall continue to hold the amount invested in SRs invested in SRs under each scheme until the redemption of all SRs issued under the scheme.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the recommendations regarding the minimum investment in Security Receipts (SRs) by an Asset Reconstruction Company (ARC)?
output:
The holding requirement for the minimum investment in SRs by an ARC is only in respect of the minimum required investment and not the entire investment. The minimum investment in SRs under any scheme needs to be held by the ARC only as long as it is a manager/trustee of the underlying assets in any scheme.

For all transactions, the minimum investment in SRs by an ARC, per SR class/scheme, should be 15% of the lenders’ investment in SRs or 2.5% of the total SRs issued, per SR class/scheme, whichever is higher. Any investment in excess of the required minimum may be divested at any time. According to illustrative examples, if the total value of SRs issued is Rs.100 and investment in SRs by selling bank/FI is Rs.40, ARC's investment in SRs is Rs. 6, which is higher of 15% of Rs. 40 (Rs.6) and 2.5% of Rs.100 (Rs.2.50). If investment in SRs by selling bank/FI is Rs.0, ARC's investment in SRs is Rs. 2.50, which is higher of 15% of Rs. 0 (Rs.0) and 2.5% of Rs.100 (Rs.2.50).

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What regulatory disparities exist between AIFs and FPIs concerning investments in Securitization Receipts (SRs), and what is the recommendation to address this?
output: Eligible Qualified Buyers (QBs) such as AIFs and FPIs are subject to different regulatory treatments. The RBI notifications dated May 16, 2018, and March 10, 2021, designate all categories of AIFs set up as trusts as QBs, but they also impose conditions, such as prohibiting AIFs invested in an ARC from investing in SRs issued by that ARC. FPIs, comparatively, face no such condition. Additionally, 100% FDI is allowed into the ARC sector through the automatic route. These differences result in a non-level playing field between AIFs and FPIs, where global players owning and controlling an ARC via FDI can invest through their FPIs in SRs issued by those ARCs, while AIFs set up as trusts are prohibited from doing so. The recommendation is that the RBI should amend the participating conditions governing AIF and FPI investment in SRs to establish a level playing field.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the recommendations regarding Net Owned Funds (NOF) for Asset Reconstruction Companies (ARCs)?
output: The level of shareholders’ equity acts as a barometer of the financial strength of a company. Shareholders’ equity provides protection against losses and makes a company less reliant on external funding. An appropriate level of shareholders’ equity also determines a company’s ability to expand its business activities. ARC regulations prescribe a minimum NOF of Rs.100 crore for registration as an ARC, and ARCs are required to meet this criterion on an ongoing basis. Beyond this minimum prescription of NOF, it is desirable that ARCs have a higher level of NOF to meet the requirement of the capital-intensive nature of ARC business. Data as of March 31, 2021, shows clustering of ARCs wherein approximately 75% of the registered ARCs have an NOF level between Rs.100-200 crore, 11% have their NOF level above Rs.1500 crore, and the rest of the ARCs have an NOF level between Rs.200-400 crore. It is recommended that the minimum NOF requirement for an ARC be augmented to Rs.200 crore, and existing ARCs may be provided a glide path to meet this requirement.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What is the Committee's recommendation regarding the National Asset Reconstruction Company Limited (NARCL) proposed by the Government of India for cleaning the books of PSBs, and the competition between NARCL and private ARCs?
output: The Committee believes that there must be fair competition between the NARCL and private ARCs to promote the objectives of true price discovery through the market mechanism. Therefore, regarding the proposed NARCL by the Government of India for cleaning the books of PSBs, the Committee recommends that the RBI should ensure fair competition between the NARCL and private ARCs to promote the objectives of true price discovery through the market mechanism. The Government of India has announced the formation of an ARC, namely National Asset Reconstruction Company Limited (NARCL), for cleaning the books of PSBs, to manage and dispose of the assets to AIFs and other potential investors for eventual value realization.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What governance and transparency measures are recommended for Asset Reconstruction Companies (ARCs)?
output: The Committee recommends several governance and transparency measures for ARCs: If an ARC sponsors an AIF, at least half the members of its Board should be independent directors. To ensure continuity in engagement of Credit Rating Agencies (CRAs), it may be made mandatory for ARCs to retain a CRA for at least 3 years, and if a CRA is changed, both parties must disclose the reason for such change. The assumption and rationale of ratings, as indicated by CRAs, may be made available by ARCs to investors upon request. For better assessment of ARCs’ performance, the regulatory return requirements may be reviewed to include flow data on relevant parameters of an ARC’s functioning.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What challenges do ARCs face in reporting data to various agencies, and what recommendations are made to address these challenges?
output: ARCs file many periodic returns to various agencies apart from RBI, including filing with the RoC (as per Companies Act, 2013), NeSL (as per IBC, 2016), and CERSAI (as per Act, 2002). Much of the data reported to these agencies is common and overlapping, and each agency has a unique format for data submission, creating duplication of efforts and potential data inconsistency. The recommendations are: (a) Regulatory return requirements may be reviewed to include flow data on relevant parameters of ARC functioning. (b) A common data staging platform may be devised that can cater to the periodic returns required by various agencies.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What updates to the Assignment Agreement and Trust Deed templates are recommended to reflect changes and expectations in the ARC sector?
output: The recommendation is that the IBA (Indian Banks' Association) should review the Assignment Agreement and Trust Deed templates and update them to reflect the changes and expectations of the sector. Furthermore, SLMA (Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Security Interest Act) may also be appropriately engaged for standardization of documents.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the recommendations regarding the deployment of surplus funds on the ARC's balance sheet and the threshold for recognizing a sponsor, according to the Committee?
output: The Committee recommends that avenues for deployment of surplus funds on the ARC’s balance sheet may be widened to include a variety of short-term instruments such as cash equivalents, money market instruments, commercial paper or other short-term debt obligations, money market mutual funds and certificates of deposit maturing within one year from the date of acquisition. The Committee also recommends increasing the threshold of shareholding for recognizing a sponsor to 20%. This will be consistent with the level of shareholding corresponding to the rebuttable presumption of ‘significant influence’ specified in Ind AS 28.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the recommendations regarding the threshold level of shareholding for recognizing a sponsor in ARCs, and what measures are suggested to address potential issues arising from this change?
output: The committee recommends increasing the threshold level of shareholding for recognizing a sponsor to 20% from the current 10% through amendment to the Act, in the interest of reducing regulatory burden on ARCs and thereby allowing them to efficiently raise equity from strategic and foreign sources. To curtail the consequent perverse incentive to peg each member’s shareholding below 20%, identification of at least one sponsor may be made mandatory. Previously, Section 2(1)(zh) of the Act defines a Sponsor as any person holding not less than 10% of the paid -up equity capital of an ARC . Further, Section 3(3)(f) of the Act empowers RBI to specify fit and proper criteria for Sponsors.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What clarification is recommended regarding the enforcement rights of ARCs under Section 13 of the Act, and how should the definition of “secured creditor” be modified to reflect this?
output: It is recommended that the Act be amended to clarify that an ARC to whom a secured debt is assigned shall be a “secured creditor” under the Act, and therefore have enforcement rights under Section 13 of the Act, even if the assignor did not enjoy enforcement rights under Section 13 of the Act. To this end, the definition of “secured creditor” under the Act may be modified by amending the closing clause in Section 2(1)(zd) as follows: “in whose favour security interest is created by any borrower for due repayment of any financial assistance or transferred pursuant to assignment, transfer, transmission, etc. of any financial assistance.” Currently Section 2(1) (zd) is as follows-  (i) any bank or financial institution or any consortium or group of banks or financial institutions holding any right, title or interest upon any tangible asset or intangible asset as specified in clause (l); (ii) debenture trustee appointed by any bank or financial institution; or (iii) an asset reconstruction company whether acting as such or managing a trust set up by such asset reconstruction company for the securitisation or reconstruction, as the case may be; or (iv) debenture trustee registered with the Board and appointed for secured debt securities; or (v) any other trustee holding securities on behalf of a bank or financial institution, in whose favour security interest is created by any borrower for due repayment of any financial assistance.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What amendments to the Act are recommended to ensure efficient debt recovery by creditors and clarify the meaning of 'substantial part of business' in relation to secured assets?
output:
To ensure efficient debt recovery by creditors, it is recommended that the Act be amended to ensure that enforcement rights under Section 13 of the Act would be available to an ARC to which a secured financial asset is assigned, irrespective of the availability of enforcement rights with the assignor under Section 13 of the Act. For this purpose, the definition of “secured creditor” under Act may be modified by amending the closing clause in Section 2(1)(zd)(vi) as follows: “in whose favour security interest is created by any borrower for due repayment of any financial assistance or transferred pursuant to assignment, transfer, transmission, etc. of any financial assistance.”

To clarify the meaning of security being a “substantial part of business” and thereby making the takeover of management practically achievable, an explanation under Section 13(4)(b) of Act may be added. One possible manner it can be explained is as follows: Security for the purpose of this sub-Section can be evaluated to be “substantial part of business” if such security was responsible for generation of at least 20% revenue of the business in the preceding financial year or the current market value of such security as determined by an external valuer is more than the 50% of total assets of borrower as per the last audited balance sheet.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: How can security be evaluated as a “substantial part of business” under Section 13(4)(b) of the Act?
output: Security for the purpose of Section 13(4)(b) of the Act can be evaluated to be a “substantial part of business” if such security was responsible for the generation of at least 20% revenue of the business in the preceding financial year, or the current market value of such security as determined by an external valuer is more than 50% of the total assets of the borrower as per the latest audited balance sheet.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the recommendations regarding the difficulties faced by ARCs in charge modification and SEBI regulations?
output: Considering the difficulty faced by ARCs in modification of charge due to non-cooperative borrowers, GoI may consider carving out a mechanism for automatic transfer of charge without borrower’s consent when a lender sells assets to an ARC. ARCs have also highlighted difficulties with respect to SEBI regulations, specifically concerning open offer requirements and the definition of 'lenders'. The Committee recommends that SEBI may extend the exemption from open offer requirements, for invocation of pledge, to ARCs in line with SCBs or public financial institutions under Regulation 10(1) of SEBI (Substantial Acquisition of Shares and Takeovers) Regulations, 2011. Further, SEBI may also modify the explanation of ‘lenders’ in Regulation 158(6) of SEBI ICDR Regulations and Regulation 10(1)(i) of SEBI (Substantial Acquisition of Shares and Takeovers) Regulations, 2011 to include ARCs. As per Regulation 10(1) (b)(viii) of SEBI (Substantial Acquisition of Shares and Takeovers) Regulations, 2011, invocation of pledge by scheduled commercial banks or public financial institutions as a pledgee is exempted from open offer requirements. SEBI amended the ICDR Regulations, 2018 and SEBI (Substantial Acquisition of Shares and Takeovers) Regulations, 2011 in March 2019 to incorporate changes as RBI had withdrawn its previous debt restructuring schemes such as CDR, SDR, S4A, etc. After the amendment, SEBI defined “lenders” under Regulation 158(6) of SEBI ICDR Regulations and Regulation 10(1)(i) of SEBI (Substantial Acquisition of Shares and Takeovers) Regulations, 2011 as all SCBs (excluding RRBs) and AIFIs. Considering that ARCs, as pledgees of shares offered as security, may require the above dispensations for their debt restructuring activities, the Committee recommends that SEBI may (a) extend the exemption from open offer requirements, for invocation of pledge, to ARCs as well, in line with the exemption enjoyed by SCBs and public financial institutions under Regulation 10(1) of SEBI (Substantial Acquisition of Shares and Takeovers) Regulations, 2011 and (b) also modify the explanation of ‘lenders’ in Regulation 158(6) of SEBI ICDR Regulations and Regulation 10(1)(i) of SEBI (Substantial Acquisition of Shares and Takeovers) Regulations, 2011 to include ARCs.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the suggested changes or clarifications in the existing taxation regulations regarding investments in Security Receipts (SRs) issued by Asset Reconstruction Companies (ARCs)?
output:
Various stakeholders have suggested changes or more clarity in the extant taxation provisions with respect to investment in the SRs issued by the ARCs. One of the matters pertains to the pass-through regime for AIF income from investment in SRs. AIFs as QBs invest in the security receipts issued by ARC trusts. Under the income-tax law, the ARC trusts enjoy a complete pass-through status and the income is taxable in the hands of the investors based on the characterization that is determined by the ARC trust. Typically, the ARC trust characterizes the income as ‘business income’. The AIF loses its otherwise tax transparent status if it earns a business income and such income is taxed at the AIF level at the maximum marginal rate, i.e., at an effective tax rate 42.74%. The Committee proposes that all income from investment in SRs issued by ARC trusts earned by an AIF should also be considered as pass through and taxable in the hands of the investors of the AIF. The possibility of a 42.74% tax at the AIF level is a deterrent for this investment to flow into ARC trusts. Large pools of capital are required for large resolutions by ARCs. Hence a pass-through regime for AIF income from investment in SRs issued by an ARC Trust is critical to the success of a competitive market for these NPAs and for maximization of recovery for the ARC.

The other matter pertains to clarity on the tax rate applicable to FPIs when they invest in the SRs issued by ARC trusts. Under the income-tax law, no specific tax rate is mentioned for taxability of interest income or upside received by FPIs from their investment in the SRs. Presently, a concessional tax regime of 5% exists for taxability of income arising to FPIs and other non-residents (on Government securities, corporate bonds, ECB, etc.), subject to satisfaction of certain conditions. A similar tax treatment may be provided for interest income earned by FPIs from investment in SRs. Also, it may be clarified that any upside arising as business income may be taxed at the rate of 20% (as it is in the nature of income in respect of securities under Section 115AD of Income Tax Act ). Given the risky nature of the investment in SRs as also the fact that significant foreign money is needed to resolve the NPAs in the Indian financial sector, it is essential that tax certainty is provided to foreign investors. The proposed changes will incentivize flow of FPI investment in SRs and help in resolution of bad loans.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What clarifications or amendments in extant tax provisions related to Asset Reconstruction Companies (ARCs) does the Government of India need to consider?
output:
The Government of India may look into the following matters for appropriate clarification/amendment in the extant tax provisions:
(a) Similar to ‘investment income’, all income from investment in Security Receipts (SRs) issued by ARC trusts earned by an Alternative Investment Fund (AIF) should be considered as pass through and taxable in the hands of the investors of the AIF.
(b) Clarity on the tax rate applicable to Foreign Portfolio Investors (FPIs) when they invest in the SRs issued by ARC trusts: The concessional tax regime of 5% existing for taxability of income arising to FPIs and other non-residents (on Government securities, corporate bonds, ECB, etc.), may be also provided for interest income earned by FPIs from investment in SRs. Also, it may be clarified that any upside arising as business income may be taxed at the rate of 20% (as it is in the nature of income in respect of securities under Section 115AD of Income Tax Act).

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What recommendations were made regarding the sale of fraud accounts to ARCs, acquisition of stressed loans, information checklists, process documents, valuation exercises, and the scope of Section 5 of the Act?
output: The following recommendations were made: Sale of fraud accounts to ARCs may be permitted subject to appropriate safeguards; ARCs may be allowed to acquire stressed loans to domestic borrowers from regulated overseas banks and financial institutions; SLMA may provide lenders with a suitable comprehensive checklist on necessary information to be given to ARCs at the pre-deal stage; IBA may provide a model process document to lenders for ensuring certainty and transparency of auctions; For financial assets of Rs.500 crore and above, two bank-approved external valuers should carry out the valuation exercise; The scope of Section 5 of the Act may be expanded to allow ARCs to acquire ‘financial assets’ for reconstruction.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the requirements for an ARC acquiring management/trusteeship of a financial asset from another ARC, according to the provided text?
output: Any acquisition of management/ trusteeship of a financial asset by an ARC from another ARC must have the approval of a majority, by value, of the SR holders concerned or such other prescribed threshold as may be defined by the subscription agreement/ trust deed. It may be clarified that any ARC acquiring trusteeship/management from another ARC, where the SRs are not extinguished, will be required to purchase the associated SRs to the extent of the prescribed minimum threshold. (RBI)

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What measures may be allowed to enhance ARCs' ability to be a prime vehicle for resolution, and what conditions apply?
output: In order to enhance ARCs’ ability to be a prime vehicle for resolution, stressed loan assets may be allowed to be sold by lenders to ARCs with suitable checks and balances. Additionally, ARCs may be allowed to participate in IBC as a Resolution Applicant either through their SR trust or through the AIF sponsored by them. This is subject to the condition that AUM by the ARC acquired through AIF and IBC should not together exceed the AUM acquired via SR issuance at any time.

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What are the recommendations regarding the Net Owned Funds (NOF) for Asset Reconstruction Companies (ARCs)?
output: The minimum requirement of Net Owned Funds (NOF) may be increased to Rs.200 crore from the existing Rs.100 crore. Existing ARCs may be provided a glide path to meet this requirement. (RBI)

instruction: Answer the question based on the provided context from the financial report.
input: Question: What measures are recommended to address the incentive to peg each member’s shareholding below 20% and to streamline legal provisions and processes for efficient debt recovery by creditors?
output: To address the incentive to peg each member’s shareholding below 20%, the identification of at least one sponsor may be made mandatory. In the interest of efficient recovery of debt by creditors, the Act may be amended to ensure that enforcement rights under Section 13 of the Act would be available to an ARC to which a secured financial asset is assigned, irrespective of the availability of enforcement rights with the assignor under Section 13 of the Act. One possible manner it can be explained is as follows: Security for the purpose of this sub-Section can be evaluated to be a “substantial part of business” if such security was responsible for generation of at least 20% revenue of the business in the preceding financial year or the current market value of such security as determined by an external valuer is more than the 50% of total assets of the borrower as per the latest audited balance sheet.
